No need to insult Bernie Sanders by comparing him to the vile Donald Trump.  It's enough to compare him to leftist 1972 Democratic Presidential nominee George McGovern who was trounced by Richard Nixon.  If nominated for President, Sanders will suffer the same fate

The election of 2016 was won by an emotion: anger. The election of 2020 is waiting to be won by a coalition of horror, disgust, heartsickness, and the will of a sane mind to wake up from a crazy dream. Add the curious shame one feels in spite of having opposed this national disgrace from the start; and, for a positive touch, the hope that never dies.

Many Americans now hunger mainly for decency and competence at the forefront of national life. That's not a surmise, but a well-reported reality. The revolution that has broad support is the overthrow of all that Donald Trump has brought on. It's not that people desire a return to any past regimen of policies, but that they see the restoration of normal governance as the essential precondition for everything they do desire. Secure the rule of law. Oust the agents of autocracy. Honor those who do their level best to serve the common good. These are the demands which Democrats will be called on to meet in the general election.

Let's not be like generals who prepare to fight the last war. The anger that will gamble on extreme measures still exists, but it's no longer where the action is.

This is an accurate comparison of our culture war political Generals.  Maybe Sanders can channel his supporters to lead a kind of American version of the Arab Spring.  And maybe then once in office he can defeat congressional opposition, the Supreme Court and ignore corporate lobbyists and media firestorms.  Then maybe--  I can't even try anymore because I've lost faith in the American political system and the electorate. 

Maybe it will just make for entertaining television.

The opposite of Trump is not Bernie who is in his own private Idaho, it’s Amy Klobuchar who is a genuine pragmatic liberal progressive who actually cares about people and America. Watch her closing statement of the NH debate. She is the one candidate to unite the country and defeat Trump.

Except, of course, there isn't anything radical about Bernie at all.  Most of what he wants is either: 

1) solid, tested, reliable American policies that we've abandoned at our peril, and seen our collective good fortune decline because of it.  Remember when Republican Eisenhower had strong taxes on the 1%, supported unions, and warned against the military-industrial complex?  You might recall that the middle class was quite prosperous back then.

2) solid, tested, reliable European policies that are currently out-performing our American policies, like socialized healthcare.  We don't have to guess how it works- we can just look across the pond and see for ourselves. 

3) responding to the environmental crisis that everyone who has a shred of intellectual honesty has known about for 30 years.  I did. The Boomers could have responded decades ago, but typically chose to be short-sighted, lazy, and selfish; leaving their mess for their kids to clean up.  After the Millennials pay off their parents debts, that is.

It would be nice if the "center" stopped teaming up with the far right to stop progress.  But they always do.

Mr. Bruni just reminded me to contribute three times today to the Sanders campaign.   This election will be the first time in my 74 years that I will be able to vote for the practice solutions that are so sorely needed in this country.  I am motivated because I know that Senator Sanders will not be squandering our blood and treasure for wars abroad.  Instead, we will be spending these trillions on helping our own people live better.

Pick up a rubber band, pull it far to the right. Now...pull it far to the left. What happens? 

The tension increases...dramatically. Eventually, the rubber band will break. 

This is where we are as a country, as a society. 

Our obsession with the cult of celebrity (Buttigieg)  - or anointing a Savior (Trump or Sanders) -  has gotten the better of some folks. When it comes to electing the President - the leader of the free world - nothing can replace maturity, wisdom, and experience. 

Then there's the "Obama Argument;" President Obama was a once in a generation exception. 

Neither Sarah Palin, nor Marco Rubio, or Pete Buttigieg - those the media made wanna-be wunderkind - possess the unique and extraordinary combination of life experiences, personal attributes, emotional maturity, razor-sharp intellect...and something-you-cannot-explain characteristics of former President Obama.

Time to get real, man-up, and make some wise choices. We are "grown ups"...allegedly. 

As adults, sometimes we must do what serves everyone best...even if it's not what we personally want.

Call me simpleminded but I believe most people have made up their minds by now. There is such a profound difference between Trump and any candidate running on the Democratic side that I don’t see how anyone with an IQ greater than their age hasn’t decided which way to vote. I firmly believe that enough Americans will rally together and remove the monster from the Oval Office. Churchill said you can always count on Americans to do the right thing after exhausting all other options. I’m feeling exhausted and see no other options.

Bernie is like a mirror image of Trump.  Hailed by fervent supporters who think he is 'authentic', making wild statements about promises that are unlikely to be accomplished and sowing dissent and discord in his own party and in the country.  If I were a Republican, I would see Bernie as the best nominee to run against Trump.

Many people, in their gut, tend to favor the strong (-looking) horse. The highschool quarterback gets the adulation, not the skinny guy who is good at Calculus and is a future multimillionaire.  Trump plays the strong-horse act well (yes I know it's an act).  Who among the remaining Democrats has that presence?    I'd bet on Bloomberg or Sanders.
It’s a nice thought, but Trump appeals to profound themes in American history that Sanders really doesn’t.  Sure, he could turn out to be Ronald Reagan. But he could also be George McGovern.

Is Bruni really suggesting, heck maybe even stating, that Bernie is the strongest Democratic candidate? 

Sometimes these coastal elites would make me laugh if the stakes weren’t so high. Bernie, unlike Biden, would get clobbered in Pennsylvania, that ever so important state where I reside. Bernie wants to ban fracking (a huge industry here) and his promises of free education and Medicare for All will turn off moderate voters. That honeymoon in the USSR will also alienate if not disgust others. 

No Democratic can win the White House without PA. Let’s stop the proselytizing and accept the realities of this election. A moderate nominee must win the Democratic primary.

That is of course, if you want to defeat Trump.

Clinton suffered one of the worst political upsets in US history.  She was over confident and didn't even campaign extensively in the areas that caused her catastrophic defeat.  The Democratic establishment wanted a neo con corporatist as the nominee.  The nation was not moved enough to prevent her an electoral college defeat.   Russian interference is a red herring the NYTs insists on marring their political analysis with.  Russia had nothing to do with her loss of voters that voted for Obama in 2012.  Sanders will not have the advantages that Clinton blew.   He is committed to his campaign 100%.  If he wins the nomination he will adapt to the political environment of the general election but he will fight and expand the boundaries beyond what main stream political commentators thought possible.  Trump is the extremist that his enemies tried to remove from office with a thinly veiled impeachment scheme that didn't impress the voters.  Sanders will have to work around that in the general election.  Focusing on the mobilization of voters and calling for a better utilization of the great wealth the US possesses to actually the tackle the dangerous misrule of Trump.
It's almost as if we need checks and balances on power and not be relying on "norms".

Bruni seems to start off by making what seemed like keen observations and then ended with strangely Trumpian leaps in logic with a confusing conclusion. To claim that if we subtract Hillary's email scandal, Comey's panicked stunt and her own heavy political baggage and you have a winner, is like saying 10 minus 6 is 2 and Bernie loses. Whaaaat?????? If Mr. Bruni also subtracts the national DNC's efforts to undermine Bernie's 2016 campaign -- a scandal which led to then Chairperson Debbie Wasserman-Schultz' resignation, Bernie might have been the Democratic nominee instead. But really, who cares now. That's over.

What's more relevant is Bruni's point that in 2016, Trump sparked widespread panic within the Republican party because the party establishment could not control him. And he won the presidency. Now, it's the Democrats turn as Bernie is causing establishment Democrats to convulse, because he is not in their control. Oddly, the 78 year old Bernie represents the new guard of the Democratic Party, who is successfully demonstrating that he can win votes while also rejecting corporate donors... and the truth is, establishment Democrats don't like that. They like their corporate donors. What's at stake here? As more and more Americans are being driven into poverty, which Americans euphemistically call "debt," if Democrats don't embrace the new path Bernie is laying down and reinvent itself as a party of the working people, we will likely become a third-world Banana Republic.
I do wonder if the democratic party and its electorate would think differently if Sanders was, in fact, a democrat.
Sanders is a populist who tells the people the truth. In that way he is fundamentally different than Trump. Indeed, Bernie is the perfect antidote for the Donald's spell.

After giving away the store to his billionaire buddies in NYC for 12 years, Bloomberg has had a recent epiphany about income inequality, that, and the injustices of stop-and-frisk. As a result, he has proposed his own progressive tax plan, which he claims he has the unique ability to implement if elected. As proof, in his recent Op-Ed piece here, he disingenuously cited his success in getting the New York State legislature to pass a tax increase after 9/11. True enough, but the fact that it had the backing of his cronies in the real estate and finance industries, both heavily affected, just might have had something to do with it; it was essentially a bailout for them, a handful of people. Sanders didn't need a sudden wake up call (by his pollsters) to promote such a plan; he's been at it for 50 years. People see in him someone who's been on-message his entire career. Does that mean he's uncompromising, or just brutally honest?

In 2016 when the Electorate wanted a radical change from the calm Obama years, Bernie might have beaten Trump.  Now, however, I believe the Electorate wants calm and stability after the rocky Trump years.  Such stability would've been provided by Biden, but he is proving a bit too old and rickety for the Dems.  The answer now is:  Bloomberg.   Wait and see.

Sanders IS trump and so are his supporters.
with Sanders as the nominee, we can all buckle in for trumps reelection in 2020.

I followed the whole Brexit fiasco over at The Independent, which provided great coverage, and you can find my comments there proving that. Despite being a progressive, I started having doubts about Corbyn when he still didn't come to a decisive stance on Brexit at the start of 2019. The problem apparently was that the Labour leader was well aware a vast majority of left wing voters, about 75%, preferred remain, but he himself wanted to leave and negotiate his own deal. Balancing between both positions made him waste too many chances to ensure a second referendum. He even missed the golden opportunity to kick Johnson out of power when Tory rebels gave the opposition a majority.

He bet everything on the election, despite bad polls, but again tried to avoid the hot Brexit potato, instead of trying to convince more voters that Tories, not the EU, were the real enemy. To ignore the overwhelming preferrance of potential Labour voters was a dire mistake and he lost the election by alienating both Leavers and Remainers.

Bernie Sanders is in a very much different situation. Unlike Corbyn, he's on the right side of history, without any big issue that puts him at odds with a majority of center/left voters, polls show.  He'll simply bring the US up to standards of healthcare  & education of other industrial nations, that's a realistic goal for this rich nation, unlike Labour's manifesto. And his polls versus Trump prove he's a very strong challenger. He'll win that election, I'm sure.

How radical could Sens. Warren and Sanders be if fmr. Mayor Bloomberg has vowed to support either if he or she becomes the nominee?

Only a handful of American voters would have more at stake from than Mr. Bloomberg would from those candidates' supposedly extreme proposals.

How radical could Sens. Warren and Sanders be if fmr. Mayor Bloomberg has vowed to support either if he or she becomes the nominee?

Only a handful of American voters would have more at stake from than Mr. Bloomberg would from those candidates' supposedly extreme proposals.

Frank, this is a tough decision to make.  In my heart I would love to see Elizabeth Warren be our nominee.  The problem is her present trajectory in the polls. I am fearful.  Then I think, well, Biden would be a good bet since he represents progression but more moderately, a safe place to be "on paper."  But where are those passionate followers like Bernie's?  Where is the enthusiasm of an Obama campaign?  Then, how about Bernie?  However, am I thinking through enough or just getting on the Kumbaya band wagon?  So, here's the deal for me: In a few weeks I will be casting my ballot, most likely for Senator Warren.  Yet, we must realize that after we tally the votes and delegates from 50 states, we ARE going to have a nominee...finally.  And whoever s/he is we have no other choice but to give our heart and soul to electing that person to the White House.  After all, every Democratic candidate is basically equal in smarts, have real moral compasses, and will put their country - us - and our democracy first.  We can make it happen, but we have to realize the stakes.  Our democracy, indeed, our Constitution can not survive under another four years of this disastrous man in the White House.  Nero watched Rome burn while playing his fiddle.  Trump will watch this nation burn before he relinquishes his play piece(s) of doom and gloom.

Rather than running down deficiencies of the various candidates, Bernie in this case, I would like to hear how the likely winners of the Democratic primaries will unite progressive, centrists, independents and Never Trump Republicans to win the election.  The litany of deficiencies is old news, and only makes people angry.  

Who might each of the leading nominees pick as their running mate?  How will they modify their positions to unite as many potential supporters as possible in the general election?   Will Bernie double down on structural change, picking someone like Warren or perhaps Sherrod Brown as his running mate, or will he chose a centrist as a running mate?    What adjustments to his policy emphases would he make to unite supporters, if any?  If Bernie accommodates to centrists, will his left wing feel betrayed?   Likewise, what might Buttigieg, Bloomberg, Klobuchar, or Biden do to unite progressive and centrists in the general election?    

This thought exercise might prove more informative in deciding who to vote for than rehashing the same old arguments regarding deficiencies.

We just don't know what will happen. Circumstances are altogether unprecedented. Frank has given us an honest and accurate assessment, without any false assurances. For that I am thankful. We do know that all of the candidates agree on the same broad set of aims and values. We do know that they would all be able to get roughly the same amount of stuff done, if they are elected. Finally do we know that any commenter or pundit who is absolutely certain that this or that candidate would trounce Trump in November is full of hooey.

"As for the argument that Hillary Clinton’s defeat proves the inefficacy of an establishment or center-left nominee, well, Clinton won the popular vote by about three million ballots and lost the Electoral College by only about 77,000, despite Russia, despite James Comey, despite a relentless focus on her emails and despite her own uniquely heavy political baggage. Subtract all of that and you get a winner — a winner who looks nothing like Bernie Sanders."

Finally! An NYT columnist making my point -- or pretty close to it. Of all the things that went wrong for Hillary, if any single one of them had gone the other way, she'd be president today. So you can't blame her loss on any single cause. Bravo, Mr. Bruni!

Side comment: It appears to me that it might be the case that visiting as many districts as you can will improve your odds of winning an election. Maybe Trump wouldn't be as popular as he is if he didn't hold frequent rallies in various places. Mayor Pete may have done well in part for his visiting as many places in Iowa as he could. Note that I said "improves your odds", so other factors will matter too, of course.

Let’s give credit where credit is due:  Bernie has finally gotten Mike Bloomberg to announce last week that income inequality is his number one priority!

Pretty amazing for a man, who in 2008, disparaged the whole Occupy Wall St movement.  Today, Mike and Bernie are not that far apart.  Mind boggling!

"Polling shows that most Americans dislike a “Medicare for all” plan that eliminates private insurance, as Sanders’s signature proposal does. Polling also shows that most Americans wouldn’t want that plan to cover undocumented immigrants. Sanders’s covers them."

Polling also showed 6 of  every 10 caucusing Iowans supported it.  And if the plan covers basic stuff that most other plans cover with a lower cost, I'll take it. Most Americans don't what is proposed in the  M4A plan. They don't know the costs. But here is what they know thanks to the negative advertising: It take away your caverage, it will cost more and bankrupt the country. Take it from someone who has tried to get good insurance. If you are not employed in a large corporation or by the state, it ain't cheap or it ain't good. According to the Mercatus study healthcare costs increase 5.5% /year set to double every 12 years. All the candidates stating that we can't afford it are lying big time.  But, split the baby and play it safe. It wins every time.

i think sanders is right about the income discrepancies that he mentioned and i believed well before he ran for president in 2016. people don't know that a universal health care plan is the way to go....eventually. obama's affordable care act was aiming that way but to get the votes he had to water it down. that is the problem i have with sanders. he is an extremist and refuses to make concessions. i too think the democrats should pick someone more toward the center left and show an aspiration toward an eventual universal health care plan but, despite whatever the courts do to the affordable care act, they try to fix that first before going off the deep end too soon. the democrats and some independents have to go with whoever the democratic convention picks. that is an imperative otherwise trump will win and instead of being a president he will the dictator of his dreams. the sanders followers have to stick to the nominee whoever it is and not do what they did in 2016 well over 100,000 in 2016 when they voted for trump. that is the nightmare that i see.

I find the comments I'm reading here about how Mr. Bruni and the centerfolds are so afraid that Bernie might win, that his socialist proposals have them sweating, that Mr. Carville and the DLC are running scared etc, to be a false narrative. 

As Paul Krugman correctly opined last week, it won't matter much which Democrat gets the nomination because Congress is going to trim their sails if they manage to win - as we've seen happen again and again when Dems have achieved majorities in Congress. All those putative centerists elected in 2018 will remain a sizable voting block. And the corporate money is still going to largely control the agenda. Getting that corrupting cash out of our system is going to take more than winning the White House.

So I take Mr Bruni and Mr Carville at their word: their concerns are about the election, not what happens after the election if a Democrat, even Bernie, wins.

Comments here from democrats illustrate a central dilemna: vote for Sanders (who has made no question of his intent to destroy the party) should he be the nominee, or stay home. The perfect nightmare, don't you think?

Pete and Bernie did extremely well in the Iowa caucuses, but with shockingly historic extremely low turnout for the caucuses. Perhaps suggesting a general lack of interest in Pete and Bernie even within the Democratic Party of Iowa. Perhaps not an excellent omen for either Pete or Bernie.

You're right, Frank, Sanders could fool the experts and win, just as Trump did.  None of us know for sure.  Sanders, a Jewish socialist from Brooklyn, by way of Vermont will, with that pedigree raise more eyebrows in middle America than did Trump four years ago, for whom middle America was willing to travel hundreds of miles for a rally.  In the heart of middle America, Iowa, Sanders did not produce the swelling turnout that he predicted he could, denied a clear victory by a political newcomer.  Trump would have done much better. That's worth consideration.

While both Trump and Sanders could be called populists there are other differences than just right  versus left. Trump tapped into something deeply ingrained in America, white supremacy. It was his immigration policy, which is white supremacist, that dominated his campaign. White supremacy is particularly important in certain regions of this country but has supporters all over the US. Sanders in contrast has policies that are basically European. What he advocates is already common in many European counties. It is not from America's past where the frontier was central until it was entirely settled. European countries did not have frontiers and had a very different history. Therefore. It is much more likely that Trump's populism can translate into electoral victories than Sanders' populism. To defeat Trump I anticipate voting for a candidate from the center-left wing of the Democratic Party. I think that is the best way to get never Trump Republicans and independents to vote for a Democrat.

Advocating for universal healthcare, which no British Conservative prime minister would ever eliminate, and which Margaret Thatcher never touched, is "risky", Frank?  Going back to free tuition for American students, regardless of economic circumstances, which was the norm before Reagan in most states, even in Reagan's California, is "risky"?  Dismantling the hated ICE, which was only stuck together into its present form in 2012, is "risky"?

Indeed, Frank, you dare to refer to the modest and humble Bernie Sanders as "grandiose and bellicose?

You can't possibly be serious!

Bruni's comparison of Trump and Bernie leads to another comparison. That is, the drive by their respective voters for a strong man who will "rescue them". The difference is, of course, Bernie will inherit a far right Supreme Court, and a Senate that will block every initiative he makes. 

And the yearning for those of us  who detest Trump for that one person to come along and "rescue us" is what has driven the disarray in the Democratic primary. As some have seen Biden fade, they hang their political fortunes on a young mayor of a town only the fraction of the size of my county. And when that candidate fails to attract the majority of Democratic voters, they will cast about looking for some other "savior".

The fact is, the Democratic candidates haven't let us down. It is we who have let them down. Millions of us should have been in the streets every month for the past three years. Can you imagine the energy behind this election - regardless of the eventual nominee - if we, as citizens, were all that committed to removing our nation's first dictator? 

We Dems have put the cart before the horse. We need to show these candidates that we will do what it takes, peacefully and lawfully, to remove this tyrant. And we have been woefully deficient. So we turn to the candidates and place impossible expectations on all of them, expecting them to do all the lifting -- and the push back that we, ourselves, should have been doing. Now the only question is whether it's too late to start.

It may well be correct that Bernie will be unable to beat Trump. But it also may be true that none of the current Democrats can either. To beat him, one must shamelessly appeal to American’s self-interest, and none of the current crop is shameless enough to outdo Trump.

Americans love Medicare, but somehow don’t want anyone except seniors to have it. They like their government-subsidized corporate plans, but don’t want those who can’t get one to get the equivalent amount of subsidy, even though many of them are paying for those subsidies. This is the American self-interest on healthcare, and Trump will pit the subsidized against the unsubsidized by protecting those subsidies.

There is probably no way to outdo Trump in this department, short of hallucinogenic drugs. We are probably stuck with Trump and the damage he will do for the next five years.

This is hyperbolic. We need to unite around whichever candidate is chosen. Progressives will be in great distress if it's Bloomberg but they will have to hold their noses and vote for him (I am one of them and I will do it). Similarly, centrists will have to get it together and vote for Sanders. I know wealthier folks feel offended or even hurt by some of his rhetoric but he really does not want to turn the US into the Soviet Union. He does want to move the country to a more just and equitable future. Moderates should be able to handle that.

Look, Corbyn went down in flames because he tried to say he was for Brexit while at the same time against Brexit; in other words, just trust him to do it better. Not relevant in this situation.

Our health care system is unsustainable. It's sad that people have to go bankrupt to find this out. Our earth is being killed by human activity. I would have thought that this would be the number one issue. Income inequality is killing capitalism, leading a lot of people to believe it is dead.

All Democrats say the health care system is fixable; do what Europe does. All Democrats want strong and fast action on global climate change. All Democrats want to take actions to restore a balance in income and wealth in the name of democracy. And ALL Democrats want to see the end of the most deplorable and corrupt leader in the history of this country, and his complicit party.

So why are all you pundits spending so much time on these silly policy nuances that have no bearing on the future at all? My preference is Warren, but I will work for Sanders, Klobuchar, Buttigieg, Bloomberg, or Biden equally as hard. And I will work as hard to remove any government official who belongs to the party that supports Trump, even at the town clerk level.

To every thinking responsible voting American, vote for your candidate in the primary, but take the pledge to vote for the Democratic nominee for every possible office in November, and drag along at least three other voters to do the same.
I have BFT — Bernie Bashing Fatigue.  Humans hate to change.  It’s so much easier to stay the same.   And Bernie represents change.   If we don’t change then we continue down the path of decline.

The main point he didn't mention , which has confounded all the political gurus is that many people who voted for Obama later switched to Trump. Many said the would have voted for Saunders if had won the nomination. It's not ideology that was the decider. But this election is different and Trump and the republicans (and some Dems) are ready for the socialist scare tactics. If the Dems abandon Sanders as too radical we could see a McGovern type defeat.

I almost (almost!) wish that someone like Biden wins the nomination and then proceeds to lose the general election so that we could finally bury the idea that a "centrist" is the only electable candidate. Then we would finally realize that the country has undergone a radical transformation in the last 30 years and the same old same old isn't going to make it. 
We'll see. I want Trump gone and I will take what I can get, but not willing to go along with the narrative that killed is in 2016.

A whole lot of panicking going on with the centrist pundits. The most radical proposal in Sanders' program is a tax bracket for the ultra rich, far more modest than under republican president Eisenhower. Their fear mongering can only be described as preposterous.

As a historian I agree.  I am as liberal as can be but I am also a little d democrat.  I resist authoritarianism and cults from both left and right.  I agree the Democratic party has forgotten its roots and what it used to stand for.  But I also feel that replacing one authoritarian with another is no solution.  While I do not believe any republican will ever again work for the common good, I resent being  subject to a purity test by a group of people who are as unwilling as the Senate republicans to put country before party.

As we wait to see just how bad the coronavirus outbreak might be, I find it very difficult to understand those who oppose medical coverage for everyone in this country, including illegal immigrants. If you don't favor it on humanitarian grounds, you should at least recognize that it's in everyone's interest to have a system in which each person in the country can get adequate and timely medical care. Denying that care makes all of us less safe both because of threats to our own health and because of the economic damage caused by epidemics, addiction, etc. Both Sanders and Warren understand this; I'm not sure the other candidates do.
While your friend can just keep on rolling his eyes, I will keep my eyes focused on Bernie, the only 2020 candidate with enough integrity and real weight.

Trump had an unrecognized advantage in 2016 while Sanders today is an almost surefire bet to lose. Trump was extreme in his desire to retreat into politically known territory, that is, to rejuvenate capitalism through deregulation and tax cuts,  whereas in this election Sanders wants to venture forth into the unknown wilderness of heavy-duty socialism and state control of the economy + major tax increases,  a place Americans have never been before--and this during economically good times when most Americans see no reason to rock the boat.

". . . free tuition at public colleges regardless of a student’s economic circumstances" . . . That sad ol' twisted talking point again!
Public college would merely be an extension of the public high school systems that now exists. It would simply now include college, so that everyone could get that level of education. 
Nobody forced the wealthy to send their kids to public high school and so many send them to private schools- this will be the same with college. Can you even for a minute think some hedge fund manager is going to send his pride and joy to a public college? Please.

Forget the voters and concentrate on the states with the most electoral votes.
Remember Hillary? She got almost 3 million more votes than Trump...and still lost!
The same thing happened to Al Gore who won about 1/2 million more votes than Bush.
If democrats are serious about bringing democracy back to elections they will work toward making the national popular vote the final determinant rather than the electoral college.

Really? I don't see Bernie Sanders as grandiose, or irascible. Righteous anger is not being irascible. And, grandiose? "Affectation of grandeur or splendor" according to Merriam-Webster. No, Bernie is neither of these. What he is, is the target of those who are worried about his "democratic socialist" agenda i.e his electability.

I voted for Sanders in the 2016 primary, but won't do that again.
While I would like to live in a Bernie Sanders's world: medical care for all, more affordable college education, a tax system that did not favor the already wealthy, etc. I don't believe he is the one to begin the task of getting us there. We need a more unifying voice with similar visions and a willingness to compromise to make the necessary steps towards that vision.
I like Mayor Pete and his brilliantly sane path, but worry about his youth and inexperience...he'll be a force to be reckoned with at some future date but not now.
I have some family connections to Joe Biden and think the world of him, but I'm his age and know what that can mean (ditto for Sanders).
E. Warren has an autobiography I've read and admired, and I would love to see Trump emasculated by someone like her. But I have serious reservations...why isn't she leading this pack now?
I had early hopes for Kamala Harris, a vision (and a sense of humor) that would have been refreshing...She will be a great AG.
And that leaves me with...Michael Blomberg. A letter from his campaign arrived a few days ago: gun control, medical care for all, climate change, etc. all the right things.
He can beat Trump, so why not? In the words of our tyrannical leader: What do you have to lose?
I like your realism, Frank. I appreciate your willingness to weld experience with principle. This is a strong piece (as usual), and also likely prescient.

The use of the terms “socialism”  and “progressivism”  was just plain thoughtless. 

All societies are arrangements in which people sacrifice their self reliance for the benefits of the cooperative efforts that reward them with more than they could gain on their own. We share not just infrastructure, national defense, courts of law, and public safety services but organized behaviors that restrict how we conduct ourselves where a lack of order means a failure to be able to do as we want together. Social security, regulations to reduce pollution or to save resources or protect us from harmful products, insurance provided without any profit motive, assistance to prevent want, and public education to assure all access to knowledge and skills to prosper are social solutions to common challenges. These benefit all of us to provide them. Labeling any as the same as the Marxist-Leninist Socialism of the Soviet Union is misrepresentation. But that is just what Republicans are attempting to do with the Democrats proposals to address health care and global warming. The Democrats who label themselves as “socialists” are inviting this, and associating leftist policies with progressivism which just confuses it. Progressives were populists who were trying to restore democracy when inequities of wealth and political power were creating plutocracy. It was not a synonym for socialism.

Mr. Bruni thinks that "Sanders is a populist of the left as surely as Trump is a populist of the right, with a familiar distaste for compromise and a comparable appeal to Americans outraged or disgusted by politics as usual and by the usual politicians."

Where this nation is today, and it is certainly in dire straits, is not the result of compromise; it is the result of decades of surrender to the failed ideology of "capitalism". 

Mr. Bruni may prefer the "compromise" of a Clinton, and Obama, or a Biden to actually fighting for the working class; he is, after all, a member of the "elite establishment", as is Mr. Sanders. Mr. Bruni has apparently forgotten that Mr. Trump was elected because he pretended to care about the working class; Mr. Sanders actually cares.

Induction, learning from the past, doesn't yield conclusions with absolute certainty. But it's the best we have to go by. And what does recent history teach us? That the American electorate punishes candidates who are too far to the left. That's what we should learn from the poor performences of George McGovern and Walter Mondale. I loved both candidates, and I worked hard for their elections. But they were too far to the left, just as Jerremy Corbin was in Britain. In order to win, the Democrats must choose a candidate who is popular not just with the radical fringe on the left of their own party, but with the grownup American public at large.

This entire article pulls at every possible centrist argument against Bernie that we've heard time and time again, but the part that really gets me is the second-to-last paragraph, where Bruni encourages us to imagine a candidate like Hillary Clinton but "subtract" the "uniquely heavy political baggage." 

Bruni, you and your colleagues just don't get it, do you?

Clinton was nothing BUT political baggage. She had made decision and decision that disappointed the American people and routinely favored corporate interests over the working-class. It is wonderful that Sanders is hardly anything like her because it's part of his appeal. He is genuine and honest, unlike Trump, and he means everything he says. And by the way, he completely trounced Buttigieg when it came to Iowa's popular vote.

Princeton is a hot bed of polling. I have spoken to many pollsters. They point out that asking people if they are happy with their present private insurance is bad polling. People will say they are happy with their insurance or their car so long as they do not get seriously ill or the car breaks down. The correct way to see how well private insurance or your car is working is to ask if you have had any problems. 

The Commonwealth Fund had a survey in which they ask people on private insurance & people on Medicare just this question. They found that people had 3 times as many problems with private insurance both in the area of coverage & in the area of payments. 

Furthermore adding just negative info to a question is bound to lower approval. Suppose instead of asking: Do you support M4A if it means giving up your private insurance? you asked: Do you support M4A if it means giving up your private insurance, & it would cut the cost of health care for the average person in half? 

Finally here is a question from a Washington Post - ABC poll: 

"Which would you prefer: the current health insurance system in the United States, in which most people get their health insurance from private employers, but some people have no insurance, OR, a universal health insurance program, in which everyone is covered under a program like Medicare that's run by the government & financed by taxpayers?" 62% favored Medicare for All; 33% were opposed. That's pretty decisive.

In the Trump Inc. Podcast, episode Sept. 18, 2019: The Family Business, there is an interesting interview with Solomon Larte (spelling ?) a records management analyst under four US presidents. He worked in the Office of Presidential Records (OPR). Federal law states that every piece of paper that crosses the president’s desk becomes part of the presidential record. Everything is forwarded to the OPR to be catalogued and filed. Everything proceeded normally until Trump became president. First, OPR found out that official docs were being thrown in the trash. Initially, OPR figured that perhaps T-rump did not know, so he was informed. That’s when Larte began receiving Manila folders of documents that had been ripped into ‘thumb-sized pieces’ by the president before being sent to the OPR. Larte said that the OPR staff were then tasked with painstakingly taping the docs back together, ‘like doing a jigsaw puzzle’. He must have been too good at that, because after 25 years, a top secret clearance, and three other presidents, he was informed that his top secret clearance would not be renewed (you’re gone). Conversely, the GOP, having proved to itself that its minions will pull the R lever if lied to sufficiently (Trump was going to invent better insurance than the ACA, end foreign wars, and protect farmers. Nuff said?), doesn't need to stoop to wonkery to try to persuade supporters.

Ambassador Gordon Sondland  should have been fired. His false presumptions were the reason President Trump was impeached. In the addendum to his original testimony, Sondland testified he warned Zelensky that “resumption of U.S. aid would likely not occur until Ukraine provided the public anti-corruption statement that we had been discussing for many weeks.” But he also testified that he only presumed aid might be denied.  He said, “by the beginning of September 2019, and in the absence of any credible explanation for the suspension of aid, I presumed  that the aid suspension had become linked to the proposed anticorruption statement.” 

When Ambassador William Taylor expressed alarm, Sondland testified he called the white House and asked for clarification. He said, “I called President Trump directly. I asked the President: ‘What do you want from Ukraine.’ President responded, ‘Nothing. There is no quid pro quo.’ The President repeated: ‘no quid pro quo multiple times.’”

The U.S. diplomats testified there was no quid pro quo; the Ukrainians repeatedly and publicly said there was no quid pro quo.   The false allegations in Article 1 solely on Sondland’s wrong presumption.

Have you ever read about the Democratic convention in 1948?

They held it in the same city as the earlier Republican convention (when Thomas Dewey was nominated)--and were so pressed for funds or time or both--

--and the GOP (graciously) consented.  

Doves were supposed to be released in the air at some climactic moment--

--but doves were not to had for love or money--

--so they made do with pigeons.  PIGEONS.

Unlike the Republicans who tend to be authoritarian and rigid, lockstep and in line and therefore have the ability to quickly coalesce around their candidates and president despite common sense or common decency, Democrats are freeform and footloose, improvising all the way.
But we are in a crisis now with trump. We may need to take a page from the Republicans' playbook and put a little more lockstep in our freeform, so that we coalesce more quickly around our candidate.  It should be easy, pick whomever can deliver the strongest knockout punches to trump. I believe Bloomberg is that person. Bloomberg is stronger, richer, smarter, and unafraid.

I refuse to engage in hand-wringing over the current state of the Democratic Party. Any candidate on the debate stage last night was a better person than Trump. Yes there is a good deal of chaos during these primaries. But politics is chaotic. Yes, there was chaos in Iowa but it should not undermine the efforts of the conscientious voters who were trying their best to find a candidate to support. Nothing that has happened so far has broken the party.  The Dems do not operate in lock step. Their earnestness is what I admire. For the most part, in this messy world, they try to do the right thing. Trump only does his thing. And most of the 
time, it’s ugly. Time to beat the ugliness. Time to get even in the most honorable way by working for candidates and casting our votes.

I am a centrist who wants to vote democratic but the party makes it so difficult to do so. I will not vote hard left because I don't want the kind of America where layers and layers of taxation blanket the nation, the government grows into a monolithic model of stagnation, and the people who lift so many boats are taxed into indifference. Again and again, the democrats show that they are not competent while the Republicans, greedy but well managed, achieve their mean spirited objectives. I am not interested in identity politics and I don't believe racism should shadow the entire democratic platform. I am not guilt-ridden by actions taken by Americans generations ago. Idealogical purity may be the Democrat's tragic flaw. I'm not crazy about someone buying his way into the political process. I'm also not crazy crazy about the fact that politicians have to spend so much precious time fundraising. I'm not crazy about the idea of four more years. So I am leaning toward Bloomberg. Whatever his failings (in our purist eyes) he is not crazy, he has run a major city. (I'm not crazy about the three terms.) He has probably read the constitution. He probably respects it. He has been on the right side of most things and the wrong side of others. I think he can do more good than harm. And it's going to take more than idealogical purity to clean up the mess that will be left after the last four years. That will be the most formidable task of the next president if we somehow manage to boot Individual 1 out.

If Americans are wise, they would realize that after this, no Republican politician should be re-elected to any office at any level, until this generation of perverts have been cleared out of the Party.

It was not a bad week for the Democrats. They were magnificently represented by Adam Schiff and his fellow managers. In addition, Senators Jones, Sinema and Manchin,  chose country and a letter of law over self-interest. 
Iowa turned to be a fiasco, but one state, even if spectacularly failed, is not a harbinger of news to come. 

Democratic candidates and their thoughtful and intelligent exchanges serve as an excellent example of what in-depth conversation between those who deeply care about this country and its citizens is and should be all about. We can hold our heads high; we have delivered and will continue doing so. History will be kind to the Democratic Party during the times of Trump's presidency. GOP and Trump, on the other hand, will be portrayed as the most unprincipled, self-serving individuals whose desire to hold to their seats and obligation to their donors make them look the other way while  this country was burning.

Every time we characterize Lt. Col. Vindman as removed for “testifying against Trump”, let us not forget that he answered a lawful subpoena from his government and testified truthfully.  He was called to do so because his job was to protect national security.  He did his job by discussing the phone call with his superiors.  He did his job when he served his country face to face on battlegrounds.
He is now being punished by his government and forced to take a perp walk for taking his job seriously and the one who committed the crime is not removed and instead applauded and celebrated.  This is so much more serious and tragic then a typical trump tantrum.

I'm a big fan of Elizabeth Warren, but I'm thinking that maybe Bloomberg is the answer to the serious challenges our nation faces. Yes, it's offensive that he's "buying" the primary process, but isn't money at the heart of our political problems? At least you know where Bloomberg's comes from.

The big guns never got turned on him in 2016 because the opposition wanted to weaken Hillary Clinton any way possible. That would change big time if he became the nominee and he's vulnerable.

Donald Trump creates fear, then uses it to his advantage. We saw it last week when he used it to unite the Republican party in a way we've never seen before. Sure Mitt Romney broke from the pack for a second, but the rest of the party surrendered any political credibility they ever had without a whimper because they are terrified of his unpredictability.

That fear is evident in the Democratic leadership race, making them appear weak, but this is only temporary. Everyone is scared about what might happen if they send the wrong opponent in to the ring with Mr. Trump and he's re-elected, so they fight among themselves to ensure the person they feel is best qualified is the one facing him.

That's all going to change once the Democrat's select a candidate. That fear the Mr. Trump creates will unite the Democratic party in a way we've never seen before. That fear will create the largest voter turnout the US has ever seen, and hopefully send a message to the entire world about how a democracy is supposed to work!

To understand current events, certain (formerly) unthinkable principles must be made clear.
- If a Trump decision is in any way involved, regardless of outcome, Trump will initially claim “victory.”
- If the facts surrounding a Trump-victory turn against the president, he invents implausible lies. E.g. The need for the assassination of General Suleiman. Or, the betrayal of the Kurds in Syria.
- Trump is never to blame, someone else is.
- Lies versus facts? In Trump World, lies win.
- Those who speak truth to Trump, or truth about Trump must be punished. Eliminated. Defamed.
- Unpleasant facts are downplayed or omitted.
Suleiman was “taken out.” Not assassinated or murdered. The nine other people who were killed in the drone attack weren’t worth mentioning.

In other words, yes, Trump can win, and that’s scary as all get-out, but that’s true no matter who Democrats nominate. 

And I’m sick of hearing about “incompetence” in Iowa. The Iowa mess happened because the caucus system is not designed to resolve a close run election between five viable candidates. It was a mistake for anyone to ask it to do so. The muddled results reflect the muddled reality. Let’s move on.

I got Trump's number in the early 70s on my first trip to Manhattan from my job on Capitol Hill. I walked into Trump Tower and saw the fake gold stanchions and red carpet and asked the doorman what was going on. He explained Trump had a book signing for his memoir. He is a few months older than I am and was aghast - what had he EVER done to warrant a memoir other than make noise? Years later I walked to the health club near the Sheraton in Chicago early on Saturday morning and saw a line three blocks long, with men and women dressed in business attire. I asked about it and was told they were waiting to audition for THE APPRENTICE, a program I never watched. I asked why they cared what this loudmouth had to say. He gave a discount to friends for condos in the Trump Tower here and then rescinded the discounts when the market proved better. He got away with it though the cheated buyers were furious. I still don't understand why anyone pays attention to a bloated real estate developer, insecure, unschooled and incurious. I also don't understand why the companies and banks he cheated let him get away without consequences.

The Democratic party should make several simple concepts their brand. Responsibility, transparency, truth/facts/reality, and math are all profoundly anti-Trump. But the fact they should transcend partisanship is itself a strong argument.

Responsibility is a word that Mr. Trump may never have used in his tweets, rallies, etc. He's the guy who said, "the buck stops everywhere," a dramatic contrast to Truman's desk sign. It covers a lot of ground.

Transparency is part of reality/truth/facts, as is math.  In his books, former Sen. Al Franken provided some excellent examples of how to make arithmetic both engaging and potent political arguments. Either let him help here or read his early books, specifically how clears up some misleading spins on Medicare and Social Security.

Finally, all the candidates should be even more forceful about backing whoever becomes the nominee. This is especially crucial for the two candidates who haven't always been Democrats -- for different reasons.

Former mayor Bloomberg should figure out how to say that he's the 10th (or 12th) richest person in the country (world) and if *he's* willing to back either Sen. Sanders or Sen. Warren, "anyone but..." prospective voters thinking of their own finances should clutch their pearls a lot less. 

Sen. Sanders should think of some way to convey to his supporters that any other eventual Democratic nominee  both deserves and needs their support. Maybe it's time to change his Senate plumage to VT-D.

To write about Donald Trump’s very good week without saying how bad a week it was for democracy is journalistic malpractice unless you work for Brietbsrt or Fox News.    What was so good about it?    He demonstrated again how petty and vindictive he is by his vulgar words and score settling against those who testified in the House hearings.   He accomplished little else except to degrade and cheapen an important honor by giving the Presidential Medal of Freedom to a man who once on his radio show said the teenaged daughter of a Democratic president was a dog. 

There are reasons to believe all the consequences of being impeached have not yet been realized.   He has made some enemies in the intelligence communities and they are people who know things.   The truth will come out.

Democrats don’t have a nominee yet.  The Iowa caucus mess will seem inconsequential as the election season progresses.   When the candidate is chosen, it will be up to  her/him to win voters’ support.   Trump will help them just by being himself.

Whatever would so-called pundits and opinionista do without elections, candidates, and errors? They’d be out of work. Right now it’s like Whack-a-Mole, pound whichever candidate stands a bit taller, so hit Pete for anything that isn’t banal and utterly safe to say. I wonder if the news media panic at the idea Democrats could actually nominate and elect a fine person to office, or would they like to keep the status quo and ride the disaster train to the collapse?

Nancy Pelosi tore an official document?  Earlier this week, this paper ran a story by Matthew Connelly about the discarding of ICE documents 
and mentioned Trump’s destruction of his documents.  This is a violation of the Presidential Records Act and no one’s calling him out.  Giuliani took personal custody of his mayoral papers which were the property of New York City.  Leave no trail of the truth.  I applaud Speaker Pelosi’s act.

The first Presidential election I remember was in 1964. That election was the last time a Democrat won a majority of the white vote.

Jimmy Carter could not win the white vote, even after Watergate and being a governor of a Southern state.

Bill Clinton could not win the white vote either, even with a similar resume as Carter.

I have a terrible feeling of despair and apprehension going into this year's election. 

Bloomberg/Abrams 2020.

To defeat a monster, one must think out-of-the-box.

I will echo what I read in a couple letters below.  If the Democrats really want to lock up the White House, they need to run a “Save the Constitution” ticket of a moderate Democrat paired with Romney or Kasich.  I am terrified by the prospect of another four years of Benedict Donald.  In 2016 some Trump supporters said America was facing a “Flight 93” election, invoking memories of 9/11 and implying that Democrats would wreck American democracy.  Four years later, and Trump is wrecking all of our long-honored norms.  Whoever succeeds Trump (assuming Trump goes willingly) is going to face the task of repairing American democracy.

I'm tired of all the fear and loathing about Trump. Become active in your local community! Continue to be the Americans you want to be! Sure, we'll take bumps if Trump is in office for another 4 years, but we should refuse to go away and stay quiet.  Stay your course, take notes, remember names. The only constant is change and one day, we in the other half will have our say.  Be ready.

Let’s put matters in their true perspective.  If Bernie gets the nomination,  he will lose the election by the greatest electoral margin in history.  Trump will win all 50 states.  The majority of voters, Democrats, will then view the next four years as utterly hopeless and intolerable.  Civil unrest will inevitably lead to mass violence.  Our democratic institutions now destroyed by Trump, the Union will divide and split along party lines.  Enlistment in the armed forces will evaporate and national security will be weakened.  To avoid another civil war, people will vote with their feet.  Minorities—including blacks, Latinos, youth, educated women, immigrants, students, and rich liberals—will move to Blue States.  Evangelicals, uneducated unemployed white men and housewives will move to Red States, primarily in the South.  The Red States Confederation’s economy will collapse.  Trump will wage war on Iran, and the conflict will quickly go strategic nuclear, with countless deaths.  The Blue States Union will thrive, and will be forced to limit immigration from the Red States.

I watched Amy Klobuchar in the New Hampshire debate last night, and I had a very good week. The Democrats have the finest group of candidates running in about half a century. 

Possibly the national media is now learning that the Iowa caucuses really don't matter much. The Iowa caucuses need to go the way of barn raisings. The national media has been over-baking that cake for a couple of decades now.

This is American politics, not a Godfather movie.

This moment reminds me of the failed coup against Turkey's Erdogan in 2016, when his government began rounding up and arresting everyone who he felt wasn't loyal to him. We're not at that stage (yet) but it does feel like we're sliding in that direction, with a "president" who is all about exacting revenge on his own people. 

Democrats would do well to sit up and take this very seriously. Now is not the time to enact purity tests and waste energy going after one another. The target should be Trump and Trump alone.

Everything Maureen notes was a predictable consequence of impeaching Trump.  There are now three polls showing Trump at almost fifty percent.  As Gallup noted, the American people don’t like impeachment.  They get even more worked up if there is no bipartisan support.  Nor can the Dem candidates get their act together.  I said months ago that there were five candidates raising so much money that all five of them would arrive at the convention making it very difficult to unite around a single Dem candidate by November.  The Iowa caucus will give the supporters of every candidate plenty of conspiracy theories to say why they should remain in the race to the end. And then there is Bernie - he can say it all he wants but half his supporters will not come out to vote for another candidate.  David Brooks also noted the number of caucus goers was way down already compared to 2016 so now we have to wonder if turnout is going to be low across the board.  And does anyone really think Bloomberg will win in any of the red states - the guy who personifies gun control?  Not me.  I hate to say it but it’s starting to look like everything is going in Trumps favor.

I am not a fan of Bloomberg. I have never liked that he went for an unprecedented third term as NY City mayor. 
I like Warren, Bernie, I'm OK with. But something happened the other day when someone was interviewing Bloomberg. They asked him if he were to get the nomination how would two billionaires fair off against each other. His answer was, "What other billionaire?" This is the kind of answer that would really get under trumps skin. I'm thinking that Bloomberg would probably be the best candidate against the congenital liar that we have as president. Just my opinion!

Maureen is right about one thing..Trump turned the SOU into a reality show. He's not the first to do it with guests etc but he did it with a master's touch. Bloomberg is a poor campaigner but he will spend a fortune. Then again Hillary spent twice what Trump did and she lost. Bloomberg almost lost his third election to someone nobody even heard of at the time.
The media are all worked up about a fractious process for choosing a presidential candidate. Press:  this is what democracy looks like. It is a good thing.

God help us. Six months ago, I believed Trump had no chance.

Now I’m terrified several Dems would lose to Trump. And Bernie Sanders at the top of the ticket would eradicate any hope of flipping the Senate. 

I can’t believe I’m saying this, but ...a Bloomberg/Abrams ticket?

Remember when the residents of Flint were so disgusted by Obama's visit that many sat out the 2016 election, handing the state to Trump.  We need a real candidate for change, not another establishment type like Hillary.  Bernie 2020

My waking nightmare is a Trump versus Sanders contest.

If so, we can expect another four years of Trump.

What would I like to see?  A unity ticket of Bloomberg and Romney.
Bernie is an Independent.  To support impeachment was listed as such.  His party loyalty has not been proven or perhaps it has.  See the 2016 election's result.

Maybe not a perfect analogy, but for those of us who remember 1968, a sense of déja vue is engulfing me.  Back then, as now, a nasty civil war in the Democrat Party erupted pitting the left anti-war crowd versus the establishment pro-Humphrey crowd.  The ensuing brokered convention was a debacle with infighting and recriminations galore.  The Dems could not recover and come together after that, and in came Nixon.  Worse yet, unlike 1968, things are going swimmingly these days for the vast majority of the electorate, and they will not risk what has been gained by handing over the wheel to people who cannot seem to get their act together or to put forward a message that will resonate.  And Bernie, I love you, but nobody wants a "political revolution;" they want ideas that work and have a chance at becoming law.
As I said, maybe not a perfect analogy, but an apt one for educational purposes, friends.  I see the handwriting on the wall, and it reads "Trump 2020."

Ms. Dowd's apt allusion to Trump's  "... black art of turning Democrats into mincemeat",  should be a warning.  

A warning that we have the clear and present danger of a dictator in the White House.  Going forward in 2020, nothing will be business as usual again. 

Democrats need to recognize that post-acquittal Trump is more an autocrat than he is a president. They need to think out of the box because there is no box now.

The article shows Melania hanging the Presidential Medal of Freedom on Rush Limbaugh. This is a chilling sight.

Trump has trumpified his entire party, the Constitution, the Executive,  Legislative, and Judicial branches of government, and the free press.

And given the FBI is answerable to corrupted AG William Barr's Department of Justice, Trump now enjoys a monarchical immunity from all investigations and oversight.

Trump also has disparaged the entire intelligence community of the United States, and the fact that again and again he takes Putin's word over theirs seals his autocracy.

So long as the media remain captive to the  daily onslaught of Trump's soap opera, he's winning.  They're like the orchestra that kept on playing on the deck of the Titanic until it sank.

Trump deserves less coverage.

oz.

Elections have become a  long and drawn out affair. They start what 20 months or so in advance of the real voting? It's a spectator show in which there is prolonged exposure to the candidates who regurgitate the same contents at the town and debates. All this leads to voters'  fatigue who feel that  enough is enough . And that causes them to vote for someone(anyone) who may not be their candidate (or the right one when it was all fresh 20 months ago). We are now in the 21st century . Do we have to follow rules from 18th century (I am talking of Iowa Caucus,electoral college,super Tuesday and all the rest from antiquity). Let's keep election process short and sweet. A few debates 3- 4 months before the finale and all states vote on the same day. Whoever gets the most votes is the winner. I am sure the founding fathers will not be offended.

Emboldened by impeachment and the complete domination of the  Republican party Trump is victorious. Watching the Democratic debate last night with the choice being between a very progressive leftist agenda or a watered down moderate one convinced me that not one of those candidates can beat Trump. Bloomberg you have my vote.

The dark but not so secret of the 2016 election is the fact that disgruntled Sanders supporters sold the democrats out by protest voting in key battleground states for trump. Yes trump did not win the popular vote. The 10-40k votes from soured Sanders supporters made the difference in those states that propelled the don to electoral college victory.
Republicans, even staunch never trumpers, hold their nose and unite behind this sorry excuse for a human being for the win (at any cost).  Democrats stick to their fractional ideology all the way to defeat.  Bernie bros will go down the same road again rather than helping to rid us of the trump scourge, refusing to realize that the longer he stays in power the further away we are from where all reasonable people want to be.

I want a Dem to win the WH.  Our nation's future depends on it. I am picking my candidate based on a single criterion: which candidate has the best chance of winning.

I’m a Democrat, and among my leaning liberal friends, no one wants Bernie as the nominee. We have an ideal candidate in Mike Bloomberg, not solely because he can effectively manhandle and unhinge IMPOTUS. He’s a brilliant and incredibly successful guy using his resources effectively and strategically for the public good. For three terms, Bloomberg effectively ran a highly diverse city with a population larger than that of 38 US states. Who else can compete with those credentials?

 Bernie supporters complain that Bloomberg is an oligarch, buying his way into the election. I say that’s great that he’s paying his own way.  In a system broken by Citizens United, corrupted by special interest money and essentially charging voters a poll tax through the demands of constant fundraising for their candidate, Bloomberg turns the system on its head.  Instead of contributing to a presidential campaign, Bloomberg provides an opening for Democratic fundraising directed to House and Senate races.  Should he win the nomination, Bloomberg will be beholden to no one but the American people. I'm not worried about the Iowa debacle - good, get the incompetence out of the way and let's get serious.  We Dems should ALL be united against Trump.  That's it- that's the most important thing.  Bloomberg is the best situated to go after him, both with a massive war chest (which will be much needed) and the resolve, experience and attitude to take on Trump toe-to-toe. Time for everyone to watch A Face in the Crowd from 1957 with Andy Griffith and Patricia Neal.  It so presciently predicted what would happen when someone mastered the art of using TV to wield political power.

It’s true the dems are in disarray because we have yet to pick our candidate,as did the republicans 4 years ago. Then our big test is to unite.
