In other words, Romney was looking for an out and McConnell wouldn't give him one. He was therefore compelled to convict. I have to believe McConnell was aware of Romney's position when he coerced Lisa Murkowski to do a mental backflip voting against witnesses.

McConnell judged Romney's defection was less damaging than Bolton's testimony. A point which vindicates Romney and condemns the rest of the Republican Senate. Trump's innocence or guilt should not be left to voters. However, the fate of the Republican majority certainly is.

The first step is firing Mitch McConnell. If you haven't already, you should make a donation to the leading contenders. Amy McGrath is currently the party favorite. Charles Booker represents Kentucky's more progressive side. Take your pick. There's about a dozen candidates to choose from.

You can also donate to the "Fire Mitch Save America" Super PAC if that's more your thing. They currently back McGrath. However, you can guess they'll pivot if she fails to secure the nomination.
I have profound respect for Romney. I disagree with him on just about everything, but the display of courage gave me chills.

I've been among this man's fiercest critics over the years.  Up until now, I've always pretty much regarded him as a cold-hearted, supercilious, sanctimonious, shallow, empty suit, willing to say or do anything to secure and maintain power.

However, it is clear that at the core of his soul, he is a man of profound wisdom, integrity, and most important, courage. 

I've never been more pleased to admit that I was 100% wrong about a person.

Well done, Senator Romney.

Mitt Romney’s speech could have gone something like this: “Since I’m not up for re election for another four years, I don’t have to fear the president and his base and, by extension, for my job. Therefore, I will vote to convict.”

Mitt Romney voted to direct all congressional inquires of the executive to the justice system to be vetted for political motivation with all the other Republicans. The second was the more important article of impeachment.

Romney did the right thing, and kudos to him for that. But it's very telling of our time when merely doing the right thing gets lauds and hosannahs. 
  A "hero" is someone who risks life, or livelihood, in pursuit of the honorable. Romney is no hero; his physicalities have never been in duress. Insulting appraisals from scofflaws and scoudrels does not make anyone a hero.

The real question is whether Romney voted his conscience or voted REVENGE!
Before we laud the man for his bravery and valor, let's think about that.

"But even Romney’s bitterest critics, left and right, ought to give him this: He voted without regard for personal advantage, without fear of partisan obloquy, and without an eye on the easy way out — all for the sake of his own self-respect.

The country would be a better place today if more people in positions of authority acted similarly."

Bravo to Mitt Romney. 

This process demonstrated the strangest voting outcome ever.  All the Democrats voted to impeach. All the Republicans voted against the impeachment. What kind of voting was that?  Loyalty, solidarity, or were crimes actually committed.

I don't understand how they are all lawmakers; they all studied the laws, they all work in the government.  So how can there be such a divide like that. Were the charges legal?  Were the laws broken?  How can there be such a divide if they all became lawyers.  I don't get it.

Mitt Romney deserves this article.  He was brave enough to stand up for truth and American principles.  He should be honored

"In other words, the exact opposite of our politicians today."

But I think Bret missed an important point.  If he believes that Romney stood up for what was right - why is he not giving the label patriot to the Democrats who pursued the facts.  We don't know what the political risk will be to the Democratic Party.  But we know Trump's actions defied the very ideals our founding fathers tried to protect.  The men and women that were Impeachment managers spoke eloquently and the truth.  Trump and his enablers responded with name calling and threats. House Democrats made sure Trump's deeds came out of the shadows, to identify what isn't okay behavior.  To make sure the threats to our democracy are out in the open.  To chronicle it for history.  Give them a thanks too Bret!!

I remember doubting when Trump first made noises about running for President, and those New Yorkers who knew him said it might prove to be the end of the Republican Party.
An autocrat has no party, just accomplices and those he has paid off. 
I have absolutely no doubt that there now will be a major effort to use the entire Party to destroy Mitt Romney. Not sure how you do that, but then when all this started Trump hadn't stacked the federal Judiciary and Supreme Court.
When all is said and done, it is how we feel about ourselves and our lives that counts, and Mitt certainly can look at himself in the mirror this morning.
Hugh

I find it difficult to be moved by Mitt Romney’s stirring words — where was he when his noble sentiments could have made a difference? Having the courage of one’s convictions matters only when voicing those convictions can have real consequences.  Sorry, Mitt – too little, too late…

What Senator Romney did was very brave. He seems to be an honorable and decent man even though he has made mistakes. His reasoning for voting to convict was awe inspiring to me because as he spoke he knew, as we did too what torture lies ahead for him. I find the sacrifice beautiful and tragic. I have been a progressive Democrat since I registered to vote in 1988 on my 18th birthday, and I say this in all honesty: I hope he does not leave the senate and I hope we get to have Mitt Romney as our President one day soon.

Mitt’s vote did not so much show him to be a patriot as it showed that there were 52 other Republican Senators who are not.  And their leader Mitch doesn’t care a thing for the law or what may be right.  Winning is everything to this Republican caucus and that means never concerning yourself with fact or right. Mitt’s vote on impeachment only kept him out of the pure cess that the rest wallow in.
Bret Stephens is the last person who should be assessing anyone’s principles, character, or courage.
The bar for heroism is certainly low and the status diluted if Mr. Romney sets the standard.

@ MadModerate -

I would argue that Constitutional norms should fade a bit in a national crisis as major as war or The Great Depression and WWII.  Not totally, but to some degree.  War was one area the framers thought some limits on Constitutional norms needed to be applied.  They didn’t think so in an economic crisis because our economy was not developed nationally that much when the Constitution was written.  Alexander Hamilton was responsible for tying together a national economy, in great part.  So it is rational to think that if they could have foreseen such a crisis, they would have provided some response to it.  (My argument against “Originalism” in interpreting the Constitution.)

Comparing FDR’s time to today is ludicrous.  Trump’s big issue (besides his narcissism) is immigration.  Immigration has clearly not risen to an existential crisis level as large the Great Depression or WWII, much less that other time an American president veered significantly away from Constitutional norms, The Civil War.  

Not every war rises to those levels, WWI didn’t, and Wilson’s and Congress’ support for the Sedition Act of 1918 was incorrect.  Turning against Constitutional norms should have a sign that says, “Use in times of GREAT Existential Emergency”.

Trump’s abandonment of Constitutional norms deserves reprimand.

A true leader inspires courage, inspires us to action, inspires the best parts of ourselves, stirs our hearts to do good and inspires hope.  Mitt Romney is such a leader.  

Although I am not a Republican I have great respect for his stand and have always thought that he was and is a selfless person with true Christian faith.

Hurray for Mitt!

When John McCain died I assumed there were no decent Republican left anywhere. There's still one. We liberals can disagree with Mitt Romney all day about dozens of issues, but we must applaud him at this moment.

Listening to Senator Romney I was reminded to Joseph Welch's remark to Joseph McCarthy, "Sir, have you no decency."  If memory serves, what followed was Edward R. Murrow's expose of McCarthy and his minions.  Senator Romney is a lone voice in a bleak wilderness peopled by spineless individuals like Mitch McConnell, Lindsay Graham and the others.  A sad time in American history from which it will take several generations to recover.

It’s heartening that Romney of all people, who has flip flopped through a wide ranging array of temporarily expedient positions over his political career would land on the right side of history in this one, shining moment.  Although insufficient in the long run to impact the outcome, his proud resistance was in sharp contrast to his GOP colleagues, whose cowering response to Trump’s blatant abuse of presidential power was to exponentially increase that power.  At least Romney’s stand showed America that character in the Republican Party - however remote - was still possible.

Kudos the Senator Romney. Still I can forgive others for voting not to convict, however all but a handful of Republicans, along with the dangerous enablers on Fox News, wouldn’t even acknowledge the malfeasance, and those people have done serious and permanent damage to the integrity and accountability of our Government.

"“I will only be one name among many, no more, no less, to future generations of Americans who look at the record of this trial,” he said in his peroration. “They will note merely that I was among the senators who determined that what the president did was wrong, grievously wrong.”
Romney's vote was, of course, the right one, but here he is being disingenuous.

Anyone who has read Edward Abbey's 
 novel "The Brave Cowboy," filmed as "Lonely Are the Brave" knows that the hero lost his life fighting for an ideal.

This hardly describes Romney, a Republican who has spent his entire life 
voting for and defending every lousy GOP idea, especially when he benefited.

As admirable as Romney's vote on impeachment was, in the end it was only symbolic. With Trump's  purges, Romney has the opportunity to act on the principles that led him to his vote against the abuse of power that, again, evident in this presidency. I urge him to take advantage of  his newly-found position and decry the Trump's actions, reminding him and the Republican leadership that, unlike the governmental system in which his friends Kim Jung Un and the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia operate, this country does not give him license to consolidate personal power in his office.

Romney's speech was unique, in that it was based on personal responsibility, commitment to an oath to be fair and truthful, commitment to the idea that to undermine the oath taken in front of God, is to undermine one's relationship with God. and country.  And when those commitments are factored, truth spoken aloud bears the only judgement: the President is guilty.

The Republican party is really big on using personal responsibility to act against the health, safety and security of Americans. We should take responsibility - if we can't afford healthcare, we should get better jobs. If we cannot afford both food and rent, we should tae responsibility for that, and figure it out - not look for food handouts or housing aid. 

Yet when it came to using personal responsibility to judge the President who takes not, the GOP went quiet. 

Mitt Romney recognized that he has to do the hard things; that makes him more honest and less hypocritical than anyone in his party.

Thank you Mr. Stephens, I have great respect for Mitt Romney, If you saw a sound bite of Mitt's speech, you wouldn't get it, too many people take cursory glances at things. Watch the entire speech America! take the time.  It is brilliant and heart felt.  Mr. Romney is a man of honor and a humility not often seen among politicians.   Thanks Mr. Stephens, I am always drawn to your articles.

Political courage makes a patriot? That leaves you out, Mr. Stephens. You slice and dice and come down on your GOP side every time. Even with the lazy, Homer Simpson kind of line: "the exact opposite of our politicians today,"  you dodge behind the "sure, they all do it" lie. And Mitch McConnell went down a dark road? No, he trashed the Constitution of the USA and declared that general elections will suffice to amend the Constitution. Truly, the Second Amendment becomes more relevant every day.

As Romney shows, there is now only one way in which a good person can remain a Republican: by openly working against his own party. But I wonder. Now that lying, corruption and despotism have openly become the "brand" of the party, is even that enough?

I am 72. For more than half my life, I took for granted that all Senators would behave as Mitt Romney did. Yes, there were partisan arguments but when the stake involved the foundations of our nation, principles would triumph over party. 
   By nature, I am an optimist. With each passing day of this foul, corrupt administration and the GOP cult following, I know that I will not live to see balance, sanity and respect for the Constitution restored. Anyone who has studied cults knows it is almost impossible to deprogram members. With trump, we have not just the idolatry of an individual but a vast industry which depends on keeping the cult alive. 
    It will take generations to undo the damage. Perhaps our great-grandchildren will once again be able to expect most of our national leaders to behave as people with discernment and integrity, regardless of party affiliation.

Like most of us, Senator Romney has had times when he lived up to his principles and times when he didn't. But faced with the hardest test of his political life, he listened to his conscience and demonstrated his courage. When he was a presidential candidate, I recall reading a piece on his commitment to his faith and the role he played within his church--including, surprisingly to me,  as a counselor to church members beset by troubles. It was clear during his speech in the Senate that he is a person of deep faith, a faith that made him obey his conscience. The contrast with those who loudly profess their faith, yet act against the tenets of that faith, could not be starker. Thank you, Senator Romney.

Mitt was a R that I could have voted for. Major reason Mitt missed my vote 2012 was that it was a vote for the GOP.

That sounds partisan but it is NOT; not in a traditional sense.  I always leaned D but have voted R and admired Rs.  I wore an "I Like Ike button";  I thought Senator Javits was a hero; Mitt was not a bad Gov.

I lean Progressive and Liberal yes but not in a partisan way.  Rather in a scientific way.  Weighing the evidence and rationality my verdict falls more often that way.  But best plan should win IF THINGS EXISTENTIALLY EVEN!  Of course the Ds not always right technically nor the Rs always wrong nor vice versa.

But I am is a patriot!  I fought for the ideals of my Country NOT for any Party.

And today's GOP is full bore antithetical to our founding ideal of secular liberal democracy, to truth, to modernity.  It is the Party of Theocratic Authoritarian Plutocracy (TAP) at any cost.

The  GOP not only counters the Progressive argument but also ANY RATIONAL AND TRUTHFUL ARGUMENT that threatens TAP!

I do believe a vote for the GOP is a vote against America!   Not because of its tax plan, or heath care plan, or infrastructure plan, or lack thereof but because their regressive path is a path existentially away from honor, truth, fairness, modernity.  It is existentially pointed away from our ideals.  The D Party for all its imperfection is NOT an existential danger; the GOP is! I vote accordingly!

“They will note merely that I was among the senators who determined that what the president did was wrong, grievously wrong.”

Senator Romney was not even the only Republican Senator who determined what Trump did was wrong - he was the only one with the courage to act.
In the end the only thing we have left is our integrity.

Very nice. But Mr. Stephens might have dared to emulate Mr. Romney by writing that our Republican politicians, and not merely “our politicians,” are the opposite in courage to the one who dares to act on his conscience. Surely, Democratic senators from purple and historically red districts showed equal courage in voting to convict. Nor are the remainder to be grouped with Republicans whose votes to acquit are the very epitome of cowardice in action.

The Republican caucus in the Senate has one hero and 52 cowards. That’s the sad reality. 52 cowards who let Trump get away with  trashing the constitution because they are afraid of being bullied by tweet.
52 Senators who failed to discharge their basic duty: to protect democracy.
Their cowardice has consequences. It’s not an abstract vote. The first of their victims: Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman who was escorted from his place of work because he stood up to the president and the 52 cowards did not.

Imagining a Democratic “Trump” is at this point in history ridiculous.

The contemporary post Reagan conservative movement birthed Trump. He is part and parcel of it. There is no similarly huge truth-denying, hate-espousing, and corrupt trend in the current Democratic Party. 

I get really tired of people trying to play Trump down as either politics as normal or not uniquely Republican. It’s dumb both-sides nonsense spouted by people who can’t take a hard look at just how badly conservative politics in this country have gone wrong.

"Conservatives used to believe this..."  No, they never did. Their "principles" were always a sham -- the alacrity with which they all but unanimously embraced Trump proves that. There are almost no principled conservatives, and never were.

I'm just so disgusted with Trump. How low he has dragged us. And now I have to read regularly about foul-mouthed, petty-minded Don Jr. What happened to the party that nominated Romney for the presidency? Ugh.

What this article fails to enforce is that the Democrat congressmen also showed bravery. The whole impeachment trial required bravery and decency. Partisanship is no excuse nor paravane to hide behind.
Those who stood up to Trump, both on the left and right, deserve credit.

Your column suggests that you and Mitt are two naive peas in a pod. The left is pursuing culturally destructive ends and will stop at nothing to accomplish them. This quaint notion that the Bernie supporters and others on the left have any intention of engaging in civil discourse about ideas is foolishness. They do not discuss, they destroy. Trump understands that but Mitt and those who pretend to think he voted to convict because he is a man of honor are clueless about the left’s brave new world.

What Romney did put to shame the other 52 Republican Senators. Of course they are indignant, it was a well deserved slap in the face and few can accept that as a rightful punishment.
He must be the coward, unable to silence his conscience like the rest of them.

My father told me a story from his youth. It was about his father seeing the funeral of FDR. It was the first time he had ever seen his father cry, and it astonished him. His father would rant and rave about FDR. He hated him. When my father asked his father why he was crying, he said because that man was a patriot. I thought they were all  gone. I was mistaken.

If it was anyone else but Romney I'd believe his actions were real. But it was Romney, so it was all fake. He denounces Trump, then vies for a top job in his administration, and then buries him in a pompous impeachment speech. That doesn't make him brave, or a true patriot. It makes him what he's always been, an opportunist. Dems will love him, columnists will fete him, but the electorate will look at him with nothing but disdain.

"[P]ermanently lost to Republicans amid their supposed victory in the impeachment saga is the hope of having a leg to stand on when, in the fullness of time, a future Democratic president behaves toward them exactly the way Trump behaved last year."
Oh please - they'll recite verbatim the pious proclamations that they issued during Clinton's impeachment, without a trace of irony and without giving a moment's thought to their blatant hypocrisy.  A "leg to stand on" isn't needed, when you don't stand for anything.

Romney showed a lot of courage when he was destroying companies and workers by sending the products and jobs to China?  He is just a RINO globalist who can’t accept the fact that Trump is president while he lost  in 2012.  Say what you want about Trump’s style and rough edges but did we ever hear a politician stand up for the working class before Trump?  Why  does Trump retain his base? Because his supporters believe that nobody else has their backs. Funny how Mitt is lionized by the left at this moment when he was excoriated in 2012. Kind of like the left’s flip flop on the IC, whom they have hated for 60 years but suddenly they are heroes because they led the coup against Trump. Sheer hypocrisy, as usual.

Romney is the only senator left in the morally bankrupt Republican Party who stands for values and integrity. Alas, the other senators in the NOTHING PARTY have sold their soul to the divisive fear mongering corrupt creature in the White House. Romney’s act reflect his love for our great nation. It is pathetic to see the transformation of Rubio, Graham, Collins, Paul and Murkowski. They will support any corruption or criminal act by con man to remain in power. Alas, they were elected to serve the people and support our constitution. Con man is transforming our nation to a banana republic as reflected by daily crimes by con man, his family and cronies and filling of judiciary by most incompetent and compromised individuals in US history. He is for sale and he would anything to destroy the basic foundation that protects the people to fatten the wallets of  the crooks. It is a shame that some people don’t see the con man’s true color. Senator Romney brings a fresh air in our current environment of doom and gloom.

«Was this the same man who denounced Donald Trump as a “con man” in March of 2016 and then auditioned to be his secretary of state that November?... »

Oh yes.  This is the same Mitt Romney who once assured us that abortion rights were safe with him and then promised he would do anything to stop abortion.  The same Mitt Romney who cheered Trump’s birther lies and who lied that President Obama was on a global apology tour for the United States.  The same Mitt Romney whose anti-immigrant rhetoric (remember self deportation?) paved the way for Trump’s anti-immigrant rhetoric.  The same Mitt Romney who once declared that he would separate his faith from our governance and who this week explained his vote by saying that his faith guides everything he does.  Same Mitt Romney.
His vote was the right thing to do, but there is no reason to think it comes from any deep principles.  Romney gave himself a moment in the spotlight and a potential starting point for a later second run at the presidency - all knowing full well it would not change Trump’s fate.  Mitt Romney is a calculating politician, as he has always been.
Lonely Are The Brave...Douglas & Matthau at the top of their game. God bless ‘em.

Romney is human with human foibles. He is a politician with a politician’s foibles. But when push came to shove he did what was right.

What more should we want?

“The right-wing vituperations descending on Romney, directed by the president and amplified through his media minions, are no better than the left’s cancel-culture warriors, seeking to wreck the lives of anyone who falls short of expectations or doesn’t toe the ideological line.”

While I am no fan of cancel culture, Stephens offers a blatant understatement, if not false equivalency. The lefties he refers to here are generally neither condoning criminal behavior nor doing so for political gain or retribution, but out of lofty ideals, even if sometimes applied overzealously.

Two observations:
 What is this "cancel-culture" stuff about the left?  It is the right that wants to regulate the private lives of Americans--the bodies of women, who may marry, whether trans persons may be treated.
And then, what will happen to the Republican party over the next decade?  Even though a minority party of the old, the white, the patriarchal, they are trying every which way to steam roll the rest of us.  Will the majority of us be able to overcome their stacking of the judiciary, their voter suppression, their Electoral College and Senate inherent inequity?  Will the Trumpian autocracy and disinformation destroy our government?  Or will it all catch up with them and the party truly disintegrate and be replaced?  It seems hard to fathom that it could reform itself.

Bravo Mr. Romney.  What a ray of light in this depressingly dark time!  That said, our democratic institutions are being burned down before our very eyes and it seems to me, we fiddle.  We truly need to take action now, before the voting.  We need young people on college campuses rising up.  We need a major boycott of Kentucky and Kentucky bourbon to hit Moscow Mitch where it counts.  We need to donate to Democrats in senatorial races.  This grandmother  is ready to take to the streets!

I don’t know about “without regard for personal advantage.” In big decisions motives are almost always mixed. How big a part Romney’s conscience played in leading him to cast his dissenting vote I wouldn’t presume to guess; generosity compels me to assume it was a large one. But knowledge of the world, of politics in general, and of Romney in particular make me assume that a calculated positioning himself for a post-Trump future played a part as well.
The question begs - if the economy was going South, how many Repubican Senators would have been more courageous.

I think Dalton Trumbo wrote the screenplay for "Lonely are the Brave."  There's some insight there for sure.   Right?  Even after all these years, I cannot shake the image of Douglas's character Burns and his horse Whiskey being struck down in traffic in the rain.  I think it got to playwright Sam Shepard, too.  I think he referenced it quite heavily in "True West."  For some of the same reasons mentioned by Mr. Stephens perhaps.   Here's to Kirk Douglas!   The best kind of American hero!   And thanks to Senator Mitt Romney for his stand.

At some point in the not so distant future, an artist will construct a memorial to the GOP politicians who supported Trump during theses times.

The memorial will be modeled on one of Dante's rings and it will include the names of each person who decided their cult of personality outweighed their oaths to defend the US Constitution.

It will be Trump's wall.  But to the people who once believed in a land ruled by laws and not by cults will have deemed it for what it was: The wall of Cowards.

I hope that the actions of Mitt Romney, who in his own words is a profoundly religious man (" My faith is at the heart of who I am.”) give courage and support to others of faith so that they can break away from the cult of trumpism and stand for truth honesty and decency and against what they know in their heart is the polar opposite of those virtues.  Let the Utah caucus results be one indication of their ability to do so.

Indeed, lonely are the brave; especially when all the rest feels attacked by one's moral courage to let them know they are cowards, thrashing the truth, hence justice, despicable minions to an egregious beast in-chief, I guess waiting to see how and when Trump may bankrupt this nation. In fact, we the people, shall be called morally corrupt if we keep looking the other way. It has been said that 'indifference kills'. True!
Since voter sentiment zigzags the Republicans will look for a ‘principled ‘ candidate next. Did they just find one?
Perhaps Romney could further his service to America by running as a conservative third-party candidate in the upcoming Presidential election? Just a thought.
One of my favorite movies.
Romney is the kind of good man that this country needs to flourish and survive.

My cousin and I watched A Few Good Men last night as we felt we both needed a booster shot of truth standing up to outrageous, unchecked power. 

What we're witnessing in this country right now is truth being stranger than fiction, although I can picture the president having a complete Colonel Jessup meltdown, scuffling with MPs as they escort him from a courtroom or the White House. 

I am no Republican, but am proud of Mitt Romney for standing up and speaking his heart, mind, and faith to a completely reckless group of Republican Senators who wouldn't recognize honor if it smacked them in the face.

Romney reminds me of one of my own heroes, Thomas Cranmer, the original author of the Anglican Book of Common prayer.  A weak and vacillating man, trying to survive in a reign of terror, burned at the stake by Bloody Mary, who at the end was able to pull himself together and do the right thing, thus becoming a martyr for his faith.  We would do well to emulate these very ordinary saints.  Courage is not the absence of fear; it is right action in the face of fear.

Why is Romney considered a hero for doing the right thing? Why is that heroic? It is expected. Apart from the fact he had nothing to lose-no election for 5 years, no money or security to lose, and nothing on the line for him-so he’s ridiculed by a crazy person on Twitter , at the National Prayer breakfast -so what-look at those who did the right thing in testifying before the House Committee-those are the heroes, not poor rich Mitt-who drove to New Hampshire with the family dog in the roof of his car!

Give me a break. This is a puff piece, placing Romney at the pinnacle of moral virtue in utterly amoral political dynamic. Romney is a republican. He is who he associates with. His party spinelessly bowed to the personality cult of Mr. Trump, aiding and abetting a man who will indeed usurp the constitution and the rule of law. 

Our institutions are buckling right now. The government seems incredibly weak. This is not a time for petty politics. The center will not hold, and thats the danger Romney faces.
He will not be too lonely; he now shares his place in history with Margaret Chase Smith, Joseph N. Welsh, and all the others who spoke the truth, inspired by character and bolstered by faith.

A well-deserved tribute to Mitt Romney. One line that perhaps doesn't ring true: "Conservatives used to believe... that political dirty tricks should never be normalized." Where does that leave tricky Dick Nixon, Lee Atwater, and the swift-boating of John Kerry? A shameful (albeit successful) record that is not matched by anything the Democrats did over the same time span.
Thank you, Senator Romney, for doing what’s right.

I’m grateful Romney did this. It was (and is) a tiny glimmer of hope in this madness. If you’ve not listened to his feature on the NYT’s The Daily (podcast), I recommend you do. He gave a journalist access to him the night before and morning of Wednesday’s vote in the Senate. Hope, and my work at securing voters for the 2020 election are what keep me going.
The contrast of Mitt Romney and Susan Collins in the vote says it all. The quiet dignity of Romney and the staged concern of Collins are worlds apart.
Well said and a great movie pick.  Douglas often said it was his favorite movie .
The best thing Romney could do for America at this stage is to enter the race as a conservative third party candidate for President.
Finally something that I can agree with. Finally a man of integrity in the Republican party.

There may be room for a centre right party now. Or even just a centrist party.
USA is in such a mess.
Ha! I watched it, too!
Hear, hear!  I was never impressed by, or a fan of, Mitt Romney. I am now, and always will be.
I will always believe in being the drop in the bucket.  Let’s all act on that belief.

the one vote I cannot understand is all republicans voting Nay on Article 2.
It was an obvious obstruction of Congress. No documents produced, no witnesses allowed to appear before House committees.
Isn't that an obvious obstruction?
I recommend another movie about one person doing the right thing, even when it means doing so by himself and defying friends and a cowardly, craven community: "High Noon."

One nitpick here: Mr. Stephens says "the opinions of [Senator Romney's] constituents" don't bind him. As a Utahn, Mitt Romney is basically untouchable here. He has earned the unshakable trust of the overwhelmingly Mormon electorate, and has a Senate seat for life (unless he gets called as an Apostle to the Church). If anything, this action has increased Utahns' respect for him—Trump doesn't have the same sort of blind support here as he does in other red states. Mormons tend to sympathize with immigrants and refugees thanks to their pioneer heritage, and Trump's insulting language about both groups is a turn-off (although many will still quietly vote for him in 2020). 

Also: this Romney constituent called his office over and over again during the impeachment proceedings to allow witnesses and vote to convict Trump. I would like to think my small actions played some small part. I may not like Romney 98% of the time, but I will give credit where credit is due.

Romney is not a hero nor do I believe he has a courageous bone in his body.  He used his religious beliefs as a smokescreen to vote against President Trump.  Romney's sincere dislike, one could even say hatred, for the President is no secret.  The wrath of the President and his Senate colleagues will be well deserved.  He may as well switch parties though the majority of the dems never showed him any respect until this betrayal.

Senator Romney's principled and courageous vote to convict shines a bright laser beam on the cowardice, dishonesty, and hypocrisy of the other 52 republican senators and should serve to make them feel ashamed.  My guess is that they are taking down all the mirrors in their houses and wearing disguises in public.  What a waste.  What injustice.  It will take generations for us to recover from this debacle.

"On some positions, Cowardice asks the question, 'Is it safe?' Expediency asks the question, 'Is it politic?' And Vanity comes along and asks the question, 'Is it popular?' But Conscience asks the question, 'Is it right?'" (MLK, Jr.)

Senator Romney's speach and vote were not safe, politic, or popular among fellow Republicans. 

But it was right thing to do. 

As the last Republican in Congress with a conscience, he will find it very lonely among the cowards, sycophants, and authoritarians that now make up the Party of Trump. 

But history (and his grandchildren and their children) will judge him kindly. That is something few Republicans in the House and Senate can count on.

I wonder what Trump's retribution will be? 
He has fired  those who testified under oath as to the truth (something he himself did not do).  Those folks couldn't vote to convict him.   Romney voted to remove Trump from office.  No small thing.

Yes, Mr. Stephens, Mitt Romney has vindicated the American ideal. Unfortunately Donald Trump is petty and vindictive and now that Romney has stood against Trump, he will be crucified not only by Trump but by the throngs of Republican congressmen who are no more than attack dogs who are blindly obedient to him.

"Conservatives used to believe this, just as they used to believe that the branches of government were coequal; that political dirty tricks should never be normalized; that embattled allies must not be enlisted in such tricks; that, as Judge Laurence Silberman once said, “The most heinous act in which a democratic government can engage is to use its law enforcement machinery for political ends”; that innocence isn’t established by the failure to get away with the intended crime; and that acquittal isn’t vindication. Among the things now permanently lost to Republicans amid their supposed victory in the impeachment saga is the hope of having a leg to stand on when, in the fullness of time, a future Democratic president behaves toward them exactly the way Trump behaved last year."
First, Republican will not care  about their "supposed victory in the impeachment saga is the hope of having a leg to stand on when, in the fullness of time, a future Democratic president behaves toward them exactly the way Trump behaved last year."

And Bret you know that Republicans don't care. If a Democratic President did one of a thousand things Trump has done, Republicans would impeach.

Mitt Romney simply repaid Trump for the humiliation he received. But he brought it on himself. Romney basically called Trump threat to the human race at the start of the 2016 race. Trump called him a loser. Than after Trump wins he calls Romney to the Tower and Romney goes thinking he's going to get some admin position. Trump was just playing with him, getting his revenge. Romney showed his real persona, no backbone. And Romney showed his true colors with his comments on poor people, caught on tape, when he ran for President. He's not brave, and as it turns out his vote means nothing.

If the Senate had more Romneys,  the country wouldn't be as divided as it is.  It's down right terrifying that only one Republican Senator had the courage of his convictions  and faith in the Constitution.  That speaks volumes about the lack of integrity  and character in the rest of the Republican Senate.

Mr. Trump is guilty of far more perfidy than he was charged with and any honest person should detest  the actions of this  'exonerated', impeached President who has the temerity to go after innocent, patriotic , and honorable people.

How it is possible that anyone can ignore his egregious, vindictive behavior and still want to support him!  It will take decades to undo the malfeasance and damage,  wrought by this corrupt individual and all who enabled him.

What Romney understands and the rest of his Republican colleagues do not  (or choose to ignore), is that Trump has poisoned our country’s institutions and character to the point where America is no longer recognizable. Indeed, another four years will finish the job. We will have lost what took 250 years to build. And we will be left with an authoritarian overseeing “we the people” clawing  each other’s eyes out. If you are marked an “enemy of the people” watch out!  This is  what was at stake in the impeachment vote. And among Republicans, only Romney chose to see. What comes next will not be pleasant.

I am sure that when, "in the fullness of time, a future Democratic president behaves toward them exactly the way Trump behaved last year" Republicans will have no difficulty whatsoever executing an effortless, 180 degree reversal, complete with a brazenly duplicitous alternate history supporting a claim to be the righteous victims of a gross injustice.

I too was moved by Romney's stand on higher principle.  It overcame my usual cynical reaction to the utterance of a politician.  Still I am left with a feeling of impotence and I fear that "a polar night of icy darkness" (quoting Weber) awaits the country.

For Trump using government power for his petting political ends is the norm, not the exception.  We saw it today, as Trump launched his Retribution Tour, firing those closest until he figures out how to destroy everyone else who involved with his impeachment.

I'm assuming the MAGA crowd will crow everytime Trump exacts more payback, in ways egregious and corrupt at the same time.  I listened to John Heilman remark on MSNBC that  Trump can't help himself, no sooner does he win a "victory" than he begins work on his next crime.

It is a crime to fire witnesses who happen to make the defendent mad for telling the truth.  Of course, proving that would be harder than it even was for Mitt to speak truth to power, and yet, after hearing his speech a couple of times, I realize, it wasn't hard at all when you have principles and want to live with yourself.

When desperate to get back in the game, and to to have any chance to win in Utah, he went to kiss Trump's ring. Casting a vote against someone you hate on a personal level, particularly when the vote was as meaningless as any vote which falls 20 short can be, is not courage sir. If anything I fear I must agree with my friends on the right, that it was a petty vindictive vote

I'd like to remind Mr. Stephens that Trump is enabled by the same GOP that he himself has spent years, even decades,  defending.

This is not a new party; these are the very same people who enabled past policies that Stephens supported, like the Iraq war,  and climate change skepticism.   Now Bret's party has lined up behind Trump, with just one dissenter. 

This is not an anomaly. The GOP did not change.  Bret is guilty of supporting, feeding, building this rotten enterprise.  Now that it has gotten too rotten for his tastes, he can't disown his legacy.
Romney is not ‘Lonely Are the Brave’. He voted to convict because he hates Trump. I wonder what his opinion would have been if he was in the cabinet.

I genuinely thought that Mitt Romney was just going to be another Flake - Jeff Flake that is - and protest Trump, but then do nothing about it.  I was completely wrong.  My hat is off to Senator Romney.  He has an abundance of integrity, I completely respect his deeply held religious beliefs and I am very glad that the oath he took to his God informed his opinion and gave him the courage to vote the way he did.  But what is tragic for this country is that he stood alone amongst Republicans.  One good man amongst a bunch of lost, scared, corrupt, shameless, morally bankrupt Republican Senators.

It is true that Romney, starkly alone among Republican senators, took his oath seriously and courageously obeyed his conscience. Based on their votes (and the post-acquital orgies of Trump worship) his GOP colleagues did not wrestle with their consciences. That is why it is laughably mistaken to assume that they will regret greenlighting presidential extortion when the tables are turned and (hypothetically) a Democratic president commits the same offense. They will just change positions again. We've all seen old videos of McConnell and Graham speaking of the crucial need for witnesses in the Clinton trial, or how it is not necessary to have committed a crime to be impeached. These absurd contradictions with their present positions do not faze them. They feel no duty whatsoever to be consistent, any more than they feel obligated to preserve and protect the Constitution. Logic, decency, patriotic principles... let's not kid ourselves that these are anything more than obsolete concepts to today's GOP. Remember that they are the same people who railed against the lack of first-hand witnesses but then voted to block such witnesses from the so-called trial. Those are the kind of people we're talking about.

Senator Mitt Romney stood up to a President who violated his oath of office. 

He took his oath to be impartial and to render a fair and just verdict seriously. 

I commend him. 

The other Republicans who took the same oath and then violated it through jury nullification should be ashamed of themselves. 

History will judge them accordingly.

Senators Susan Collins, Lemar Alexander, Bob Portman and a score of their colleagues capable of shame, who hoped to hide their cowardice in Republican unanimity, will be eternally discomfited by Senator Romney's oratory and vote on the matter of impeachment.

Romney bolstered my faith in our republic against the Big Lie the GOP has become so enamored with.

I sent an email to Mr Romney's office months ago crewing him out for not standing on his principles regarding our corrupt president. Now I am humbled by how brave he is by following his convictions in light of scary consequences for himself and his family. But the process against Trump involves many small and large steps. Mr. Romney can now inspire us all to stand up against the bully in the White House.

Romney simply did the right thing informed by an objective evaluation of the facts, no more, no less. In any ordinary time you would have had most members of congress following the constitution and their sworn oath to protect and defend it by voting to convict Trump based on the facts. But the republicans have clearly made the classic deal with the devil. Riches, fame and power in exchange for their souls. What’s shocking is only how quickly and transparently it happened. It’s not that Mitt did something particularly heroic, he could become an independent tomorrow. It’s how low and completely corrupt his party has become in the hands of Trump, that makes what should have been a matter of course, voting guilty, make him seem the prodigal senator.

Whatever motivated Mitt Romney to make a seeming courageous stance doesn't matter.   What matters is that he seemed to actually take a position on principle.   Senator Romney is one of the few politicians that any of us will ever witness standing up for democracy.   

Others in his party gave speeches to an empty chamber glorifying why they would not bring Donald Trump to a real trial.   Senator Romney thank you for allowing some of us to have hope beyond the dark days of the most corrupt leader in the history of the United States.

Senator Romney's vote this week moved me more than I ever would have expected it to. The NY Times should have put his words at the top of their front page: "Attempting to Corrupt an Election to Maintain Power Is About as Egregious an Assault on the Constitution as Can Be Made." It was no news at all that the McConnell Senate once again neglected their Constitutional oversight duties and continued their assault on our democracy. Given the viciousness, vindictiveness and dishonesty of Trump and McConnell, the big news was Romney's bravery and decency, which moved me to tears.

Trump seems to have some sort of mojo that dissolves the courage of anyone opposing him in the republican field.  I have wondered what is this ability, i really have, because I have always perceived Americans to be a gutsy country.  But with him, just 1 of his party displayed a shred of courage. One!  What is it that melts their spines, I wonder?

Congratulations to Sen. Romney. 

In the summer 2016, I dined with a college classmate, a longtime moderate Republican operative in Washington. He told me the consensus on now-president Trump was that he was  "psychotic." (My classmate wasn't pleased, and left the GOP last year.)  

So the Republicans knew who and what they were electing in 2016. Bravo to those willing to do the right thing now, finally.

Big Deal!  The house is on fire and one and only one lonely Republican Senator, whose not up for reelection until 2024, stands up and make an honorable, decent gesture.. The rest of them act like pathetic sycophants. I learned a lesson from this debacle, which apparently did no harm to Trump and in fact seemed to have helped him. The Democratic strategists, if there are any, better become a lot more sophisticated and cunning . Attempting to  land a knockout blow on your opponent and then missing and ending up off-balance will not win the contest. In fact it could cost you the fight. At this point,  the Democrats look desperate, seem to be exercising poor judgement  and appear overmatched. They need to reexamine their approach to winning in 2020 and come up with a tough, realistic well thought out strategy  and then implement it as if their lives depend on it. It's getting very late in the fight.

When I was young, I thought that people who testified under oath felt a genuine obligation to be truthful, and maybe that was once largely true, but not oaths seem meaningless.

Also meaningless is the spirit of the law.  

But this is not all Trump's doing.  Republicans have been fighting to destroy America for decades now, whether by trying to reduce voting, or by rebranding bigotry as religious freedom, or when losing (at the state level) by passing laws that reduce the power of the victorious Democrat to govern.  

And now with the ending of New Yorkers ability to get what amounts to an easy pass on air travel, we see the use of public power for vengeance.  

The next step?  Reporters in jail?  Civil servants in jail?

Senator Romney shows that he's aware of something that seemingly all other Republicans have forgotten. The US is a representative democracy. Congressmen and -women are not delegates who can only act on the specific orders or in line with the wishes of their constituents, their responsibility is first and foremost to their country. We all know that Trump was guilty of the charges. No witnesses came to his defence, simply because they all knew full well that they would have had to lie under oath. The Republicans have only managed to prove once again that they are nearly as shameless as the president himself.

I'm not sure why it is so hard for Republicans to do the right thing? One in 53 Senators is less than 2 percent. Shame on every one of them, but Romney. They will go down in history as the enemies of democracy and patriotism.

Romney's rationale was succinct, powerful and moving.  So why in the world was it unique?  It stood in such sharp contrast to the pretzel logic offered by his Republican colleagues to excuse the inexcusable.  It beggars the imagination to figure out how they can live with themselves.

The towering ideas in American history have always been simple, pure and appealing to our best selves.  Romney's message resonated in those veins.  By contrast, the convoluted statements offered by the president are none of those attributes...rather, the pathetic rants of a feeble (and possibly degenerated) mind.  The contrast between the two is impossible to ignore.

Yes, I'm a sucker - I read the article because the headline made me wonder whether Mr. Stephens would really mention the Kirk Douglas film. He did - well done. But then I ended up reading this, which I knew (in one form or another) would be there, even though I had hoped against hope to be spared:

"The right-wing vituperations descending on Romney, directed by the president and amplified through his media minions, are no better than the left’s cancel-culture warriors, seeking to wreck the lives of anyone who falls short of expectations or doesn’t toe the ideological line."

Yes, as always, no criticism of the right can come without an "equivalent" critique of the left. And yet, at least the cancel culture (which I too abhor) is about disappointment with people who fail to live up to high ideals. While the attacks on Senator Romney - as is the case generally in this Trump Era - are about anger at someone for failing to stoop to the gutter.

When will opinionators like Bret Stephens and David Brooks take ownership of the role that right wingers have played for decades in nourishing the soil in which Trumpism flourishes? They paved the way for this man's ascent in a thousand ways, in the name of tax cuts. and nation-building in America's image, and winning the culture wars. Now we're all reaping the harvest.

Mitt Romney, the lone wolf of bipartisanship, though certainly brave,  is a less a symbol of courage to me than a steward of right over wrong. He outclassed a classless president and his posse of sycophants, to do what is inherent in us all, namely the desire to choose decency over deceit. Doing the right thing can be arduous and uncomfortable but it brings rewards and a refreshing taste that the bitterness of blind adherence can never offer. Heroes and cowards experience the same fears, heroes just react differently. A stubbed toe is a weak man's deferment,  but the strong man never even realizes it's there.

An inconsequential vote, since the result was already fixed, on an inconsequential issue. Trump's Ukrainian transgressions are a sideshow: his Presidency would be just as much of an abomination with or without them. Impeachment was likewise a distraction.

The real issue is why 40% of Americans supported Trump and Trumpism and will do so again later this year. This will have to be addressed in the voting booth, far from the Senate and any of its high-minded or not so high-minded denizens.

We could expect the president to be vindictive against Sen. Romney along with his best pals at Fox News. What's surprising and saddening is that other GOP senators are so fearful of Trump's wrath that they're piling on and shunning him. Have they forgotten that they are part of a co-equal branch of government? The president is at their mercy if he wants judges confirmed and his pet projects funded. Are these accomplished individuals (mostly millionaires) so fearful of being primaried because they are not otherwise employable?

This column says a lot more about the cowardly lot of Congressional Republicans than it does about Mitt Romney himself.  What can be said about an entire party so determined to protect the bully in the White House that the lone person upholding his responsibilities becomes a profile in courage?

If parties were reversed and a Democratic President beloved by a rabid base were impeached for undeniable abuse of power, how many Democrats would commit professional suicide to do the right thing? Surely less than a handful.

Mitt Romney is a brave, decent and patriotic American. So too are Jeff Flake, Justin Amash, Marie Yovanovitch, Alex Vindman and Fiona Hill.

Let's also tip the hat to dyed in the wool Republican thought leaders and opinion writers who have been excommunicated from their political home for pointing out that the current President is unfit, people like Bret Stephens, Ross Dothat, David Brooks, Bill Kristol, Peggy Noonan, David Frum, Steve Schmidt and many others with whom those of us on the left often disagree, but share a love for core American values and basic human decency.

Former Navy Secretary Richard Spencer must also be acknowledged for literally sacrificing his career to stand up and do what's right.

I agree with everything here with one exception. That future Democrats are now capable of doing the same that Trump did, and that is something Republicans should be concerned about. One of the political advantages that Republicans and their media supporters have over Democrats is their lack of morality as they more consistently lie about their policies, enact laws that provide unfair advantages at elections, such as voter restrictions and accusations of voter fraud that lack any evidence whatsoever, and then casting the opposition as undemocratic. This trend has reached its zenith with Trump as rival politicians are regularly described as “corrupt” and “evil”. This is how democracy dies while Republicans win.

Well Mittcertainly sounded sincere and unambiguous yet his past record takes away from the strength of his commitment.

Always came across as a straight forward individual, somewhat airy and presumptuous with a slight elitist tone. But believable and likeable.

For whatever he accomplished in his political career it is sad that on the eve of his tenure he chose to break from the pack so abruptly.  His remaining days will be bitter and sad, he should have taken the high road not the downhill path. 

Perhaps this is the pyrrhic victory lap that has eluded him for so long.

Governor Romney's  claim that his oath to God bound him to his course of action has been used throughout history by tyrants and mass murders to justify all kinds of despicable acts.   Nowhere in his speech did Mr. Romney say that he had examined the evidence and used reason to come to his conclusion, only that he knew in his heart what was right.  While I am quite certain that Mr. Romney believes that God speaks to him directly, I for one am relieved that this man did not become President.

It is interesting how thoroughly morality has become relative and expedient among Republicans. Yes, what Romney said was refreshing, compared to what other Republicans have been saying and to what Romney has said in the past. Still, Romney has five more years before he has to face an election. He voted for only one article despite a very strong case for two. He voted to avoid having to listen to evidence. He also knows that if the GOP resurrects itself in the future or a new Conservative party forms to replace it, he will need at least one tiny profile in courage in his portfolio.
There are a lot of true conservatives and religious leaders showing vastly more courage and integrity. For Bret Stephens to ignore them in order to read and reread Romney's little squeak of defiance is pretty patnetic.
Bravery is always more likely to make an appearance when it is reinforced by a couple of hundred million dollars safely in the bank.

Perhaps Stephens best essay.  Eloquent.  I'd just add that Romney is 72 and still has almost five years remaining on his Senate term.  One wonders if he would have done the same thing if he were up for re-election this November.

Hmm "lost is the hope of having a leg to stand on when, in the fullness of time, a future Democratic president behaves toward them exactly the way Trump behaved last year" I was alive when FDR became your president; I find it impossible to believe any future Democrat (or, less hopefully, Republican) President would or could behave like this.
The echoes of the Gettysburg Address, in the quoted passage, seem too close to be a coincidence.

Finally Mitt spoke up and showed some backbone. I don't believe he deserves all of the kudos he is getting because he did the right thing. He had many other opportunities to speak up and did not. As far as the other Republican senators go I can only be comforted with the old adage "what goes around comes around"

As a longtime resident of Massachusetts I never voted for Mitt Romney nor liked him as a person. I thought he lacked backbone at times holding his finger to see which way the political winds are blowing. However, everything you say about him appears to be true. He seems to have arrived at a moment of clarity in his public life, and reacted in a brave and noble way; defending what he thought was right without the fear of the consequences. My opinion of him has changed.

I find this column truly unbelievable--all of it--and I know for a fact that I have a lot of company that feels the same way.  I actually cannot imagine that even Mr. Stephens believes this paean to Mitt Romney but, since he wrote it, maybe he does.  Rather than bravery, nobility, morality, among all these other god-like qualities Mr. Stephens touts, all I see is a small, petty, spiteful and vengeful man.  Truly:  Losing a presidential election seems to leave a person diminished, bitter, and forever changed.

I don't understand Mitt Romney. When Governor of Massachusetts he moved to the left, for example by implementing an early version of something similar to Obamacare. As a presidential candidate in 2008 he moved way right on various issues, including denouncing his own health care program in Massachusetts. When Trump won, he dined with him in an attempt to get a cabinet spot in his administration. Now, as an elected senator, he is the only Republican to vote for Trump's impeachment, thus ensuring his ostracization from the GOP for the remaining five years of his Senate term. Maybe somebody from Utah can tell us what he is truly about.

Romney's choice and legacy will stand the test of time because it was truth to power.  McConnell and minions will be thrown in the waste bin and their legacy (like Trump's impeachment) of failure to choose country over power will be forever.

I agree Bret re Romney.
But please stop the false equivalences.
The so-called cancel culture is not on par with having the power of the US federal government and a major propaganda network at your disposal.  Not even close.
The Republican Party of Trump is not some aberration. We are now at the logical conclusion of a process started by Richard Nixon over 40 years ago.  And you cheer lead that process all along the way. Up until now, anyway.
We have not arrived where we are now by accident. Please accept some personal responsibility for your part in it.
Romney has made up for his ill-advised meeting with Trump after the latter's election.And he has done  so with style and gravitas.
Someday Senator Romney will lead the effort to rebuild the Republican Party.
The joke of it will be that when Trump is finally out of office he will be totally abandoned by all his fairweather " friends". He will be the lonely one although certainly not the brave one.

When historians rake through the ashes of the corrupt and divisive Trump Administration and the complicit GOP they will record that, in this moment when so many failed this country, as did our two Senators from North Carolina,  there were a few men and women stood firm in the face of the caustic gale of Trump's fear machine and didn't break. 
Mitt Romney will be among them.

"when, in the fullness of time, a future Democratic president behaves toward them exactly the way Trump behaved last year."

"The right-wing vituperations descending on Romney, directed by the president and amplified through his media minions, are no better than the left’s cancel-culture warriors, seeking to wreck the lives of anyone who falls short of expectations or doesn’t toe the ideological line."

Really? Mr. Stephens is still looking for some kind of equivalence in American politics? There's nothing approaching a Trump or a Limbaugh on the left. American politics have devolved into the Democrats on one side,  and the apologists for, and champions of, authoritarianism on the other. It's unseemly for Mr. Stephens to attempt to stand in the middle, casting even-handed aspersions.

I have suggested that Utah being Utah, Democrats make a gesture which is a rebuke of Trump, by not putting up a candidate when Romney comes up for re-election.  There is no chance that a Democrat would be elected and it would be a recognition that being honorable is not the road to political defeat.

I found what Romney did was inspiring. His references to his faith and belief in “higher judgement” came around the birthday of Bob Marley who in his anthem “Redemption Song” references his faith in the line “My hand was made strong by the hand of the almighty”. Sounds like Mitt. How dare Trump question anyone’s commitment to faith and prayer? How dare so called evangelical leaders not condemn Trump’s attack on Romney’s faith? Sadly, they are not alone. I know ultra orthodox Jewish leaders who also give Trump a pass as Trump tramples on so many moral and religious principles.

Romney deserves praise, but I wish he hadn’t spoiled his otherwise excellent speech by devoting so much argument to whether tRump was justified in wanting Ukraine to investigate Hunter and Joe Biden.  That obviously was never a good-faith attempt to see corruption prosecuted. Why give tRump any credence in a speech otherwise devoted to fundamental principles of good government?

The statement "One man with courage makes a majority" is often - but wrongly - attributed (as Stephens does) to Andrew Jackson; the Director of the Jackson Papers Collection says Jackson never said it.  A similar line is also wrongly attributed to Thomas Jefferson.  But the line "Any man more right than his neighbors constitutes a majority of one." was actually written (in "Civil Disobedience") by Henry David Thoreau.
