I agree with you, Bret, about Senator Romney’s courage in voting for conviction, but you’re mistaken in believing that Republicans will not be able to object if a future Democratic president acts as Trump has. “Do as I say, not as I do” has always been their mantra. They got the vapors when Obama proposed spending to pull the country out of a recession—“the deficit! the deficit!” they cried—but applauded Trump’s ill-advised tax cuts which exploded the deficit, now at $1 trillion and rising. Watch how quickly they’ll be screaming “Impeach!” if a future Democratic president tries just one of the underhanded tricks that Trump pulls on a daily basis. It matters not what the crime is, only who is the perpetrator.

I was very pleasantly surprised by Romney’s Speech, and Vote. My Husband, not so much. He is a born and bred Mormon, fallen away from the Church, but knowledgeable. Romney was never in danger politically from ANY Vote, but He would have suffered a loss of respect by collaboration in this heinous miscarriage. And that’s exactly what happened: a miscarriage of Justice, of Senate Honor, of American Pride and Protocol.  The LDS Church knows a Conman when they see one, and behave accordingly. 
   Thank You, Senator Romney.

Our rights as citizens are based upon the law not our personal wealth or influence as long as our government is based upon law not powerful political entities. That is how we can be assured that each of us is free to make our own decisions and to have equal rights with respect to the rights guaranteed by the Constitution. Without that rule of law, rights and our access to our government will be determined by the personal power and influence which we have. Those who have more power would dominate over those who do not. 

We already see the vulnerability to our equal rights with respect to political parties, those who have more money and influence tend to dominate in the political parties. But the rights we have guaranteed in the Constitution and our ability to vote and have it count is still protected fair reliably by the government. 

Trump's ability to violate the law and to use the authority of his office for personal advantage as he has done, actually nullifies a government ruled by law and replaces it with a government in which law depends upon political power. And that does not just pose a threat to Republicans from a Democratic President who defies the laws but from a Republican President, as well. Trump illustrates this with the way he attacks Republicans who fail to remain loyal to him.
Let me point out, as Mr. Stephens doesn't, that Mr. Romney voted once to convict, but also once to acquit.

Romney was correct and courageous when he called Trump a “phony and a fraud” in 2016.I applaud him for casting his vote to charge Trump,with Abuse of Power, but why couldn’t he find a way to also vote for Obstruction of Justice, which was just as obvious.? Romney explained that his religion was important to him, that it is “the heart of who I am”.That was a touching moment, most of us honored this emotional statement.Trump,had no feeling for that moment and mocked Romney-Trump does not have a conscience and disdains free speech.Other Republicans should have had the courage of Romney-they are frauds who never intended to honor the oath they took at the beginning of the trial-it was a sorry spectacle of weak and unprincipled men and women.

One of my favorite films! Seen it three times.

Good for Mitt. Let's do what we can in a flood of writings, blogs, and online comments to support him.

Senator Romney:

I agree with almost none of your political stands. That said, your vote was, in essence, an act of faith. An oath means something, and an oath to God (big G), the litmus of our ability to stand for anything. 

Now even more faith will be called for. Thank you for doing the right thing. No more, no less. 

The great GK Chesterton once said, “anything worth doing, is worth doing badly.” This extends to acts of courage. Would that we all take small acts of courage—a kind of faith, really. The months ahead will demand it.

Dear Mr. Romney,

Thank you for being so strong in the face of so much adversity.  I admire your courage.

I'm somewhat torn between, "Good boy Mitt" and "Sorry, too little too late, Mitt."

In any case, Trump will not be defeated here online or in Congress. One lesson of the Sixties and Seventies is that if you want to make significant change in a very divided nation, you cannot count on electoral saviors but, rather, must take to the streets and make it clear that there will be no business as usual in America unless the opposition is listened to. In any case, online is the Entertainer-In-Chief's game, and if you play it, he will win, as today's latest episode of The Apprentice demonstrates.

For a very mild, in-the-streets warm-up, if you live near one of Trump's hotels, golf courses, or other garbage dumps, instead of spending time complaining online, how about going out and picketing Trump's place with a large sign that has a picture of Col. Vindman on one side with a caption saying:

Col. Alexander Vindman
 A True American Hero

and on the other side a picture of Trump saying:

  President Bone Spurs
A True American Cowarde,

Senator Romney did a brave thing there, and I respect him for it. But I am not entirely surprised because he had already shown at least once before that he has a line that he won't cross. While it's true that he auditioned for a job in Trump's administration, it transpired later that after that awful dinner they shared, Trump told Romney he would like him to take back the negative comments he had made about him during the primaries. Romney responded that this, he cannot do. 
He didn't get the job.
And I have an idea he has been doing a happy dance about it every day since.

That was one of the best written and delivered speeches I have seen and heard in my 64 years.

And how sad that NO other GOPer had anywhere near the backbone and courage that Romney had. 

I believe that it is up to people like you, Mr. Stephens, to stand up to Trump. The rest of the GOP and conservatives seem to have completely lost their way. They seem to live in fear of Trump. Near king-like, how scary. Nothing less than the rule of law is at stake. 

First they came for LTC Vindman.....

Let’s not forget that Mitch had a father who was denounced, rejected and ridiculed for denouncing the Vietnam war.  I am hardly a Mitch fan, but I accept his reasoning and I believe it relates to deeper values that he learned in his family. When I think of George Romney today, I think of someone who had the courage of his convictions who flew in the face of critics for what he believed was right. I wish we had a few more Romneys to find fault with. We might not have a world where I could agree with the politics but we would have a world where I could at least respect the politicians.

The saddest thing is that there was a time, not all that long ago, when Mr. Romney likely would not have stood alone among Republicans with his vote to acquit. There was a time when people could, at least on occasion, make a principled stand in spite of pressure to tow the party line. Let's remember that nine Republicans voted to acquit Bill Clinton on at least one of the impeachment charges in his trial, including Susan Collins. What's happened to you, Susan?  And let's not forget the late Senator John McCain voting against the repeal of the ACA, or seizing the microphone from a supporter to cut off a racist tirade against then-candidate Barack Obama.  How unfortunate that Mr. Romney was the sole Republican who could bring himself to do the right thing on this occasion.

I live in TX and wrote to my two Senators to watch Mitt's speech as to why he voted like he did.  It was moving and authentic.  I told my Senators that this is what courage and patriotism really looks like.  Since they are incapable of showing any integrity, I felt it was important to give them an example.  Both Cornyn and Cruz are shameful examples of what happens when you think the end justifies the means.  Mitt showed that the "means" matter.

We should also give more than a nod of appreciation to Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia.  His state gave 74% of its vote to Trump in 2016 — could not have been politically easy to vote for imprachment.

Republican apologists like Bret ever eager to see a silver lining and grab at the slightest hint of redemption among the current GOP brigade.


While Romney is clearly an infinitely more decent person than Trump and most of the GOP cabal, I wonder what his vote would have been had it been a decisive vote....


Remember Romney did go looking for work in the Trump cabinet after his election, it's not like Trump was any less appalling back then.
I never thought I would say this, but here goes. I agree with Bret Stephens.

It take more than courage to substantiate and validate an opinion, but requires conviction as well, and while understanding that it is lonely when standing strong and apart from the power to be found in numbers, Senator Mitt Romney has reminded some citizens of the courage it takes to be a true patriot.

It is a form of heroism that Mitt practiced and  I respect it.

It would have meant a lot more if he had the moral conviction to stay with the principles that allowed him to be elected in Massachusetts while he was running for president.

And if we are searching for true heroism, I am still waiting.
Once Mitt Romney did the right thing it became clear the Republicans did the wrong thing and that it was a choice.

Mitt Romney had no crisis of conscious when he ran Bain Capital, buying out troubled companies and putting thousands of Americans out of jobs all the while getting rich.  But when it comes to voting to impeach a president, knowing full well that his vote won't make a difference, he gets religion and breaks rank.  Mr. Romney is not mentally balanced.

This is a pretty low bar for heroism.  
By the time Romney is up for election in 4 years this will be forgotten.  And if not, and he gets voted out, he will be fine.
Consider the anonymous people who testify against a gang or volunteer for the armed forces and are wounded or speak up about malfeasance at their workplace...or pushed back against McCarthyism.
Romney isn't dying on any hills and saying that he is belittles those who literally and figuratively do that every day.

Senator Romney's vote was particularly courageous because it could not make a difference in the outcome. He could have chosen the politically safer route and stuck with the majority. Instead he chose a politically sacrificial and honorable path.

It is shameful that several Republicans voted against impeachment, principles and ethics merely because their careers were on the line. What is the worst that could have happened to them? Not getting re-elected. They would have still retired with generous government benefits that can only be dreamed of by most retirees. And there is nothing to prevent them from seeking better employment opportunities. Being on the right side of history would have been an added bonus. 

It is for this reason that the Democratic Party should make an exception and do something equally honorable. I propose that they not field a candidate to challenge Romney's next re-election bid. By all means, a third party candidate can challenge. But the Democrats should do something honorable to honor an honorable impeachment vote.

In 1956, John F. Kennedy wrote "Profiles in Courage" about 8 former politicians who took principled but politically dangerous stands.

Senator Romney clearly took what he conceded was a dangerous stand; but one which might be judged by history as a principled one. A "one night stand" may not match the courage shown by the 8 former politician featured in JFK's book; but it is a start.
He is keeping his head, but I still put Romney’s stand up there with that of Thomas Moore at least as portrayed in A Man for All Seasons.

I don't question the man's religious conviction but I do question the purpose of his vote - he seemed to make a deeply personal choice for his own benefit with no benefit for the people of Utah.  And while liberal columnists like Bret see great courage in one Republican voting against his party, I doubt we would have seen the same heroic labels on a Doug Jones or Joe Manchin had they defied the democratic leadership.   And that is what is so embarrassingly transparent about the sudden love for Mitt.

The thing I wonder about is what McConnell thinks is going to happen when the Dems get a majority in both houses of Congress. Do you think they are going to play by the "old" rules, or the new post-McConnell rules? What does he think they are going to do if they get a Supreme Court nomination they don't like in an election year? Or maybe any year?

The thing is, trashing the rules of the game only works if you plan to stay in power forever. Does he really imagine that the Republican party is going to retain power forever?

And yeah, respect to Romney. He's old school.
Its low hanging fruit, but for once I can say I agree with Mr. Stephens on something. Well said.

What a great tribute to an incredibly courageous act of conscience by Mitt Romney.  Out of 100 Senators he is the only one that we KNOW voted on what he thought was right versus what was politically expedient.  At the same time it is incredibly sad that he had to stand alone.  Trump’s subsequent treatment of him further vindicates his decision

In all the pieces I have read about the impeachment I haven’t seen anyone bring up the fact that currently having popularly elected senators may make a significant difference when compared to a trial with appointed senators. Senators unafraid of being primaried would seem more likely to display moral courage. Any political scientists or historians out there capable of elaborating upon this difference?

2024 is a long way off, we can't know if Mitt Romney will run for president, I don't suppose he knows yet either, but to leave that door open he had to make the speech he made and vote as he did.  It's probably going too far to praise him as a hero of moral integrity when what he did was, at bottom, a political calculation.  As a senator from Utah his action has little political downside risk, but a lot of upside potential-- he made a kind of investment judgement, something he has long experience at doing.

I will buy this. I am glad Mr. Stephens mentioned the Romney flip-flops but I am also on board with forgiving Romney for that disaster of character. I am judging him on what he has done recently. I am continuously shocked at the lack of character in the GOP. I was horrified by the Bush 43 administration but I could have never envisioned a US government so horrific and corrupt. I just don't understand how adults can act as the GOP does.

In the horror of this foregone impeachment and acquittal, I thank Romney for interjecting some hope.  He was graceful, eloquent, truthful, conscientious, and independent-minded.  It makes me recall a time when the team politicians mostly played on was not D or R, but US.
Yes, I am moved by Romney's courage, too. Guts and principles. Integrity. Thank you, Mr. Romney, sir.

Fabulous commentary. 

Mitt Romney may go down in history as the last Republican, but I fee like something happened.  I feel his act was a moment of greater historical significance than the impeachment itself.  I was moved and inspired.  

I had forgotten what it felt like to be moved and inspired.

If this sordid Republican Party ever seeks to regain it's respect and goodwill (and my vote), it will require someone with character like this to lead it. His words and actions are an impressive display of leadership and honor to his oath to defend the Constitution.

I was wrong about Mr. Romney in 2012. I thought he was a chameleon. (He was then, as Mr. Stephens pointed out.) But he was right about Russia all along, even prescient. He has been right about Mr. Trump all along too. A lot of Republicans were, too, if you go back an reread their scathing remarks about him in 2016.

How servile they all have become.

Except Mr. Romney picked up the mantle this week. He's the new leader of the Republican Party because he's the only one who's leading. 

He may be leading a party of one.  He may be the last Republican.

Mr. Romney proved to me that he is worthy of the presidency.

Mitt Romney displayed the kind of integrity that our government and Constitution require for survival.

Oversight of the executive by the House is required by the Constitution. 
The House did its job. 

The Republican Senate betrayed the government and the Constitution by their refusal to fulfill their obligations. 
The Chief Justice sat mute while ignoring blatant miscarriage of justice before him. 

The Constitution has been rendered meaningless for the time, and there are no guarantees that it can be rescued from its enemies - the enemies within.

I remember viewing a tape of Romney speaking at a Florida fundraiser back when he was running for pres. 
In it, he referred to The White House as a "fortress and a "palace."
My immediate reaction was that it's neither having always been taught it's "The People's House" and occupied by any individual at the American People's discretion.
Now, look who is in residence.
Anyway, it's time to start eviction proceedings.

Just couldn't help thinking about one man, deserted by everyone. his family his only support and inspiration. Oscars this weekend and High Noon epitome of this theme. Excellent Move Mr. Romney. Excellent Movie that captures the Heroic.

I was so impressed with Romney, I may give serious thought to voting for him if he runs again. Speaking truth to power. He showed what faith and fidelity to the Constitution look like. He is a profile in courage.

One would like to say Trump was impeached due to the lofty ideals of expressed by Mr. Romney but that would be untrue. Or perhaps because Trump was a threat to our democracy but again that would be a lie. Trump was impeached simply because the Democrats could not control their hatred. In my long life there has never been this degree of pure hatred for anyone in the White House of either party, including Nixon. Democrats despise the fact that Trump won in 2016 and for three desperate years they have tried everything to undo those results. The public sees this. And like all hatred, it destroys the ones that unleash it. Trump now has the highest approval ratings in years. Only the Democrats could have accomplished the impossible feat of making Trump appear sympathetic. Thanks to the Democrats, Trump's the favorite to win in 2020. Impeachment was merely hatred disguised in lofty principles.

While I was distressed by the faux Secretary of State offer Trump pulled and Romney bit-on; I expected he would not go-along to get-along when he would truly besmirch his family, country, and personal name

 'Mitt' will not be a laugh line as Trump expected. 

'Mitch' at some point will be given to fewer and fewer new-born boys in America over the next few years. Ditch Mitch will become a collectable campaign button. If there is already an old one it will increase in value, say well over the two-bits its namesake is worth.
I hope Romney does not run for president. As a Rockefeller Republican, who almost always vote democratic, I would vote for him.

I too commend Romney’s patriotism and bravery, and he surely will experiences recrimination from Republicans.  It helps that he is a mature, secure, thoughtful man who is not a showboat and has nothing to prove.
Agree! Robert Bolt’s “Man For All Seasons” comes to mind. Of course there’s also Sophocles’ “Antigone” and other stories about personal conviction.

Amidst my rage, frustration and resignation watching Republicans disown the Constitution ,the rule of law and oaths
to god.....then there was Mitt,,,and for a brief shining moment
among days of darkness was a reason that people fought and 
died for this country, this idea of truth and justice and liberty.
   I never much liked him before, but in that moment that he spoke the truth,at least partially, I loved him. He brought  tears  to my eyes and a respite from my bitterness; a pause to my anger.  I owe him a debt of gratitude .
      Thank-you Senator Romney.  God speed.

Yes, Romney is to be commended for his vote on the first Article of Impeachment. But if he, indeed, considered Trump guilty of misusing his office for personal gain, why did he vote not guilty to the second Article, i.e., that Trump obstructed justice by preventing witnesses and documents to testify and be entered into the public record...a real trial?
So, one or two cheers, perhaps, for Romney, but not three.

Thank you for writing this, Bret. I wrote to Senator Romney yesterday to thank him for his moving speech and his vote to convict the president. I needed to witness a Republican act for the betterment of our nation and not a party or a president.
"Lonely are the Brave" is a great film.  The screenplay was by Dalton Trumbo, a true hero.
A fine essay and encomium.  Even a great one.

Senator Mitt Romney simply voted the facts, his conscience, ever conscience of modeling integrity and honor for his children and grandchildren.

All senators take an oath to do the same.

However, at this time, under this president, such a democratic act is now heroic.

For at this time, this president will see he "will go through some things" unheard of in a  constitutional democracy of .

Shameful and counter to our great country of checks and balances.

It is up to every freedom loving American to vote to keep it so.

Thanks for this line of thought.  Having been raised 'out West' by the grandchildren of pioneers, I appreciate and miss terribly the sort of character that you are ascribing to Senator Romney. Our family always considered the sort of courage he displayed to be indicative of the presence of the 'western' spirit. While I have disagreed with his politics in the past, I heaved a grateful sigh when I learned that he had the backbone and strength of character to stand up to the bullies in his party.  Kudos to him.  Meantime, I long for the day when our political system retrieves at least a sheen of morality and graciousness.  I miss, we miss, being a nation that at least tries to be a beacon of justness, dependability, intelligence and good behavior in the world.  This week, Mitt Romney showed the world what that looks like.

As Schiff and others have noted, being alone meant more bravery was required: for Romney to say what he said and do what he did.

Trump has learned many lessons, though none of the most important ones.

Hopefully, others are learning some of the important ones.
Such as  There are in fact three branches of the national government, which are supposed to check and balance each other, not one soap opera applausometer-contest-chosen 4 year White House celebrity.

I too have reread Mr Romney's senate speech. His votes to impeach  were undertaken for the right reasons and provide a lesson in moral and ethical reasoning, something completely lacking in the current senate majority. I believe that those of us who care about such matters  will remember not only Romney's vote, as well as the craven republican senate actions.

I am, without any doubt, a Romney critic, but I have to agree: "He voted without regard for personal advantage, without fear of partisan obloquy, and without an eye on the easy way out — all for the sake of his own self-respect."
What bewilders me is that a principled stand such as his has become so noteworthy.

Keep in mind, though, that Trump is not terribly popular in Utah. In 2016 he received just 45% of the vote, and Utah was the only red state in which Trump's popularity actually decreased after the Republicans released the Access Hollywood video.
Mr Romney has reaffirmed that there exist things bigger than the GOP, and bigger than Trump.  It seems incredible that such reaffirmation was required, but someone had to do it, and hats off to him.
I'd wager Mitt is considering a run in 2024--as an Independent, of course, having effectively excommunicated himself from what remains of the GOP.

Romney has been a political skater for decades. Is it possible that he found religion, as we used to say?
Perhaps the repugnance generated by the worst and most harmful political figure in our history gave him a vision which he lacked for decades. Let us hope that regular people, those  who go to work every day and try to pay their bills on time, vote with care and thoughtfulness. The republic must survive.

Romney's actions in the Senate made me glad I voted for him when he ran for President years ago.
If he had won, what a different world we would be living in now.
If anything Romney’s vote was the end of the Grand Old Party. It’s not the party of Bush, McCain, or Romney any more,  took Trump less than 4 years to remake it in his image.

To Sen. Romney,

Thank you for upholding the ideals and beliefs that make this country that “shining city upon a hill” even if now the luster is a bit tarnished. Thank you for having the courage to stand upon your convictions knowing what surely follows. Thank you for being a lone voice in the wilderness this nation now finds itself in. I despaired the lack of people of character and decency. I’m not naive to the realities of hard ball power politics, but it’s gone way too far, and you now have set an example for men and women of honor and good intentions to aspire to. Your stand, while immensely costly personally, is appreciated and inspires hope that we will ultimately emerge from the current nightmare before it’s too late. Thank you , Sen. Romney.

As Susan Collins voted to have witnesses after McConnell had the proper nosecount, I'm skeptical.  Romney's vote was not the 67th vote and the Senate count remained below 50%.  So he gets a pat on the back for resisting being one of the government hating majority whose nose rings were firmly tugged by the Senate President in the opposite direction.
Thank you Mitt Romney. His children and grandchildren will be super proud of him, like his father before him. Amazing American family that make us proud. Stay safe from Trump vindictiveness kindly.

You are right about Senator Romney, Bret, and I never thought I would say this: that he is indeed a Profile in Courage.  I do not usually agree with Romney's policies since we are on either side of the political spectrum.  But it is with gratitude that we now have a decent and honorable man in a suspect Republican Senate who can step into the large shoes of John McCain.  One person makes a difference, you know.  Just like one life saved in war or epidemics makes a difference.  And maybe that one individual, Mitt Romney, will with time influence his colleagues on the fence between self-interests or service to others, between oaths to their God or oaths to a wayward, corrupt, and amoral "president."   I hope that his constituents in Utah, made up of many a strong Mormon, appreciate what he is doing for their, our, Constitution and democracy.  That is the bottom line, you know, for us all to save it and keep it moral and ethical.

How is it brave to vote based on evidence and common sense, instead of being a marionette animated by your voters?

I was taught that the members of the House of Representatives express the direct will of the people and that members of the Senate are supposed to moderate the inevitable slide into mob rule, hence their terms of 2 years and 6 years respectively.

Seems to me that half the Senate has forgotten their elementary school civics lesson.

I'm in such grief over the current state of affairs.  Mitt Romney's speech didn't give me hope for the future, which I think dark and bleak; however, it did provide me with some substanance that some humans are still capable of heroic acts. I always though Romney a Mormon lightweight, but I recognize heroism - an overused term these days - when I see it.  Bravo, Mr. Romney!

In today's political world, Mitt Romney deserves praise. However, one has to wonder if he was temporarily blinded while his head was frozen in a block of ink to miss the obstruction. It was neither secret nor subtle.
